Magic Guard.description: Hisuian Arcanine is a fearsome wallbreaker, using Magic Guard to eliminate the recoil from Life Orb and its incredibly high-Base Power STAB moves and prevent chip damage from entry hazards. Morning Sun allows Hisuian Arcanine to have defensive utility, being a useful check to Pokemon like Scream Tail and Iron Moth. Extreme Speed offsets Hisuian Arcanine's middling Speed and allows it to pick off chipped foes. Stealth Rock lets it leverage its good offensive typing against common Defog users like Corviknight and Mandibuzz to function as an offensive entry hazard setter, while Will-O-Wisp debilitates switch-ins like Great Tusk, Swampert, and Zamazenta, greatly dampening their damage output. Hisuian Arcanine greatly struggles with being revenge killed by faster threats like Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Zamazenta, so it appreciates defensive teammates like Corviknight and Manaphy. Slow pivots like the aforementioned Corviknight and Manaphy can help give Hisuian Arcanine more opportunities to wallbreak. Hisuian Arcanine can struggle with Well-Baked Body Steel-types like Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Skarmory, so teammates like Sandy Shocks and Zamazenta can help by breaking through them.

Sheer Force.description: Gengar makes for an amazing wallbreaker, breaking through offensive threats like Gholdengo, Great Tusk, and Enamorus-T, as well as having a decent Speed tier. Focus Blast hits Dark-types that try to switch in such as Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon as well as Steel-types such as Heatran and Hisuian Goodra. Nasty Plot turns Gengar into a threatening wallbreaker, allowing it to 2HKO RegenVest Hisuian Goodra and Manaphy with its coverage options. Sludge Wave hits Fairy- and Grass-types like Enamorus-T, Hisuian Electrode, and Ogerpon-W. Energy Ball hits Ground-types like Swampert and Great Tusk, while Thunderbolt hits non-Volt Absorb Corviknight and Mandibuzz. Gengar is great at threatening physical walls like Corviknight and Deoxys-D, so it partners well with physical wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Chien-Pao; in return, they can pressure special walls that Gengar struggles to break through like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey. Due to Gengar's frailty, it struggles against faster threats such as Azelf, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao, so defensive switch-ins to them like Mandibuzz, Great Tusk, and Intimidate Corviknight make for good partners. Gengar greatly appreciates Knock Off support from Pokemon like Swampert, Manaphy, and Deoxys-D to remove Assault Vest from RegenVest Pokemon such as Swampert, Hisuian Goodra, and Meloetta, allowing it to have an easier time breaking past the opposing team.

Normalize.description: Normalize Gengar not only threatens to remove opposing RegenVest pivots, often the best check to more conventional Gengar sets, but also reliably sets Toxic Spikes and wins one-on-one against slower setup threats like Swords Dance Iron Hands and Calm Mind Cresselia. Mean Look in conjunction with Skill Swap traps and removes opposing specially defensive walls like Swampert, Manaphy, and Empoleon that are aiming to check it. Skill Swap also reliably forces out and generates a free turn against any Pokemon slower than Gengar such as Sandy Shocks and Beads of Ruin Walking Wake, as they will be unable to hit it through Normalize. This makes Gengar one of the most reliable Toxic Spikes setters, as it threatens most common removal options like Corviknight and Great Tusk. Gengar is an excellent teammate for fast special cleaners like Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Iron Moth, as they benefit tremendously from opposing special walls being removed or weakened with Toxic Spikes. Gengar struggles against teams with fast Dark-types like Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, and Chien-Pao, as it cannot meaningfully damage them and is immensely threatened by them, making Pokemon like Fluffy Corviknight and physically defensive Manaphy great partners; they can also provide a slow pivot to get Gengar in safely. Weather Ball from Pokemon with Primordial Sea or Desolate Land bypasses Normalize, meaning Gengar cannot reliably force out common users like Walking Wake and Volcanion, so sturdy checks to them like RegenVest Swampert and Blissey make solid teammates.

Magic Guard.description: Hisuian Electrode is a great offensive pivot thanks to its amazing Speed, access to Volt Switch, and powerful STAB Chloroblast for Ground-types like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Sandy Shocks. Thunder Wave cripples switch-ins like Roaring Moon, Hisuian Goodra, and Ogerpon-H, potentially letting Hisuian Electrode's teammates outspeed and threaten them, while Leech Seed lets it chip down walls such as Blissey and Hisuian Goodra and heal. Worry Seed removes Volt Absorb from walls like Corviknight and Empoleon and Regenerator from Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, letting it chip the latter two, especially with entry hazards on the field. Hisuian Electrode forms a great VoltTurn core with other offensive pivots like Barraskewda, Roaring Moon, and Slither Wing, as they can bring it in on physical walls like Corviknight and Great Tusk, and it can bring them in on special walls like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta. Entry hazard setters like Heatran, Scream Tail, and Deoxys-D are great teammates thanks to hazards wearing down Hisuian Electrode's switch-ins like Roaring Moon, Hisuian Goodra, and Heatran; in return, it can threaten common hazard removers like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Mandibuzz. Hisuian Electrode struggles to break through specially defensive walls like Blissey, Hisuian Goodra, and Meloetta, so physical wallbreakers like Ceruledge and Galarian Zapdos are appreciated. Hisuian Electrode is also frail and has a middling defensive typing, so slow, bulky pivots that can take a hit and safely pivot it in like Corviknight and Swampert make good partners.

Wall.description: Chansey acts as an extremely niche special wall and is typically found on fat or stall teams looking for a check to setup sweepers like Volcarona, Cresselia, and Iron Crown. Seismic Toss prevents Chansey from being a sitting duck, limiting its passivity by dealing decent chip damage. Heal Bell provides extremely valuable and rare utility by allowing Chansey to act as a cleric, removing status from teammates like Pecharunt and Mandibuzz. Stealth Rock allows it to provide more general utility for its team, allowing it to wear down offensive threats like Roaring Moon, Azelf, and Deoxys-S over time, whereas Thunder Wave debilitates foes while enabling teammates like Hex Gholdengo and Pecharunt. Protect is a niche option that lets it scout out which move a Choice-locked foe like Ceruledge, Roaring Moon, or Azelf will use, easing prediction and allowing the right play to be made. Unaware lets it comfortably check special setup sweepers like Thundurus, Iron Moth, and the aforementioned Volcarona. Chansey's relatively low Defense and susceptibility to Knock Off from users like Roaring Moon, Galarian Zapdos, and all Ogerpon formes make physically bulky Pokemon that can switch into them like Great Tusk, Fluffy Corviknight, and Iron Hands good teammates. Entry hazard removers like Great Tusk, Mandibuzz, and Corviknight are greatly appreciated due to Chansey's vulnerability to hazards, allowing it to more effectively act as a special wall.

No Guard.description:
Zapdos is able to take advantage of No Guard to spam its normally inaccurate but powerful STAB moves and reliably spread paralysis with Zap Cannon. U-turn does solid damage to Roaring Moon, and lets Zapdos pivot out against special walls like Swampert and Iron Treads, generating momentum for its team. Roost gives Zapdos longevity, letting it check Great Tusk, while Heat Wave hits Volt Absorb Corviknight and Bulletproof Iron Treads, which normally shut down Zapdos.

Zapdos fits on balance and bulky offense teams, where it enables other offensive wallbreakers with paralysis and U-turn support. Zapdos matches up well against physically defensive Corviknight and Manaphy, so it's a great partner to help physical attackers like Kingambit and Chien-Pao wallbreak. The Ogerpon formes are especially good teammates, since they outspeed and threaten paralyzed Roaring Moon, even if it has Choice Scarf, while also handling Swampert and Iron Treads. Zapdos is weak to physical threats like Chien-Pao and Zamazenta, so it needs backup from physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Pecharunt. Zapdos is also threatened by faster special attackers such as Latios and Deoxys-S, so RegenVest users like Swampert and Manaphy are appreciated.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Galarian Zapdos is an excellent wallbreaker whose power is further boosted by Sword of Ruin. Boasting two powerful STAB moves with excellent neutral coverage in Close Combat and Brave Bird, Galarian Zapdos can most notably 2HKO Deoxys-D and Intimidate Corviknight. Knock Off beats Gholdengo and hinders switch-ins like Fluffy Corviknight and defensive Zapdos, while U-turn allows for pivoting against Fluffy users. Adamant is the preferred nature for better odds to 2HKO Intimidate Corviknight, while Jolly allows Galarian Zapdos to Speed tie with the plethora of base 100 Speed Pokemon, at the cost of only 3HKOing Intimidate Corviknight. Galarian Zapdos is a relatively slow and frail wallbreaker and is forced out by offensive threats such as Azelf and Chien-Pao, so it appreciates being brought in by pivots such as Azelf and Iron Moth; in return, it can threaten special walls like Swampert and Hisuian Goodra for them. Slow pivots like Corviknight and Swampert are also appreciated, as they can take a hit for it and pivot it in safely, with the former also providing entry hazard control, extending Galarian Zapdos's longevity. Galarian Zapdos struggles against Fluffy walls such as Corviknight, so Fire-types such as Ceruledge and Iron Moth make for great teammates. Stealth Rock setters such as Great Tusk and Deoxys-D are also good teammates, allowing Galarian Zapdos to always 2HKO Intimidate Corviknight; in return, it can threaten opposing Great Tusk, preventing it from removing entry hazards. Galarian Zapdos's wallbreaking prowess is further empowered when paired with other offensive threats such as Barraskewda and Roaring Moon, as they can wear down shared checks like Fluffy Corviknight.

Magic Guard.description: Galarian Zapdos is a threatening physical wallbreaker thanks to its high base Attack and powerful STAB moves in Brave Bird and Thunderous Kick. Magic Guard prevents chip damage from Stealth Rock as well as Rocky Helmet, which is commonly used by Corviknight and Skarmory. Thunderous Kick is used because the Defense drop it causes allows Galarian Zapdos to KO Pokemon like RegenVest Iron Hands with Brave Bird afterwards. Knock Off allows Galarian Zapdos to threaten switch-ins such as Gholdengo and Deoxys-D while OHKOing Iron Boulder. Galarian Zapdos can use U-turn to function as an offensive pivot as well as to switch out on uncomfortable matchups such as Corviknight, Skarmory, and Fluffy Mandibuzz, while Close Combat can be used as a second STAB option that, unlike Thunderous Kick, OHKOes Archaludon and has a very high chance to OHKO specially defensive Garganacl and Chansey. Galarian Zapdos struggles against physical walls such as Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Skarmory; special attacking wallbreakers like Sandy Shocks, Iron Moth, and Heatran are heavily appreciated, since they are able to counter them. Galarian Zapdos is also threatened by fast foes such as Dragonite, Iron Boulder, and Deoxys-S. Teammates like defensive Gholdengo and Fluffy Corviknight are appreciated to counter both Dragonite and Iron Boulder, while special walls like RegenVest Manaphy and Swampert can check Deoxys-S.

Moltres.comments:
Other Options

Scorching Sands is an alternative to Solar Beam or Will-O-Wisp that threatens Iron Moth, Iron Treads, and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo. Magic Guard + Life Orb with Brave Bird and Flare Blitz takes advantage of Moltres's offensive capabilities, and Magic Guard complements Moltres fantasically due to its granting immunity to Stealth Rock. However, this set lacks viability due to Moltres's suboptimal Attack and Speed stats.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Special attackers like Gholdengo and Latios threaten to 2HKO Moltres.

Physical Attackers: Physical attackers like Zamazenta, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao all can OHKO or 2HKO Moltres.

Knock Off Users: Knock Off users like Roaring Moon, Manaphy, and Swampert threaten to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from Moltres, which is very important to keep it immune to Stealth Rock.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Zapdos and Sandy Shocks are able to OHKO Moltres.

Desolate Land.description:
Thanks to its solid stats, decent typing, and great utility moves, Moltres can wall the tier's many Water- and Fire-types. Desolate Land lets Moltres wall Ogerpon-W, Primarina, and Swampert lacking Stone Edge, with the latter two being unable to pivot with Flip Turn. Solar Beam threatens Water-types like Manaphy, Swampert, and Primarina, whereas Will-O-Wisp punishes physical attackers like Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Iron Hands. U-turn helps generate momentum for Moltres and its allies. Roost gives Moltres longevity against dangerous wallbreakers like Cinderace, Ogerpon-H, and Iron Moth.

Moltres works best on bulky offense and balance teams due to its valuable utility and defensive capabilities. Teammates like Great Tusk and Swampert benefit from Moltres being able to check threats like Primarina, Ogerpon-W, and Iron Moth with Solar Beam. Moltres is heavily reliant on its Heavy-Duty Boots due to its massive Stealth Rock weakness, so Knock Off users like Roaring Moon, Swampert, and Great Tusk are very threatening; therefore, it appreciates Knock Off absorbers like Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Skarmory. Special attackers like Gholdengo, Zapdos, and Latios threaten Moltres, so specially defensive partners like Swampert, Manaphy, and Iron Treads are quite helpful. Moltres is also vulnerable to physical attackers like Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Chien-Pao; thus, physically defensive allies like the aforementioned Great Tusk and Corviknight work well with it. They also help Moltres by removing Stealth Rock, which is very threatening to it if its Heavy-Duty Boots have been removed.

Choice Scarf Regenerator.description: Choice Scarf Regenerator Mew is a strong utility pivot that checks fast physical attackers with the combination of Will-O-Wisp + Volt Switch while still pressuring defensive cores with entry hazards and Trick. Ice Beam can be used as an alternative to Spikes to pressure Pokemon like Garchomp and Landorus-T. Trick can be used to neutralize support Pokemon and defensive pivots like Corviknight while serving as an emergency stop to bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Enamorus-T. 136 Speed EVs with a Timid nature ensure that Mew outspeeds Chien Pao, Hisuian Electrode, and +1 Jolly Quaquaval, as well as positive natured Slither Wing and Heatran after Trick. Bulky teammates like Corviknight, Garganacl, Zapdos, and Skeledirge benefit from Mew's ability to spread burns and set hazards, allowing them to absorb more hits from physical attackers and whittle down these attackers more quickly; Mew can also pressure fast attackers like Meowscarada and Talonflame that they struggle with. Additionally, late-game cleaners like Chien-Pao, Hisuian Arcanine, and Quaquaval benefit from Mew's ability to chip defensive switch-ins and hinder walls by giving them a Choice Scarf.

Prankster.description: Prankster Mew is a good dual screens lead for hyper offense teams thanks to its good bulk, Speed, and movepool. Taunt blocks foes such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Iron Treads from setting entry hazards, Corviknight from clearing screens with Defog, and opposing setup sweepers like Volcarona from taking advantage of free turns. U-turn lets it pivot into its teammates and potentially re-set screens later in the game. Stealth Rock or Spikes can be used over U-turn to chip foes for teammates to KO. 96 Speed EVs and a Jolly Nature ensure that Mew always moves first against opposing leads like Prankster Corviknight and Masquerain, allowing Mew to hinder them with Taunt. Prankster Mew should only be used as a dual screens lead on hyper offense teams. Teammates such as Chien-Pao, Polteageist, Volcarona, and Roaring Moon all appreciate screens, which allow them to easily set up and make them less susceptible to revenge killers. The aforementioned Pokemon also provide good options for Mew to pivot into and gain momentum. Dark-type Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Meowscarada, and Chien-Pao are immune to Prankster Taunt and can take advantage of Mew, so counters to them such as Zamazenta-C and Triage users, like Enamorus-T and Ursaluna, are good teammates.

All-Out Attacker.description: Life Orb Mew is a very dangerous mixed wallbreaker that can decimate various walls with its colorful coverage. Ice Beam hits Ground- and Flying-types such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Zapdos. Gunk Shot 2HKOes Scream Tail, which otherwise switches into Mew freely. Close Combat takes care of Blissey and Steel-types such as Hisuian Goodra, Kingambit, and Heatran. Flamethrower 2HKOes non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight and Zamazenta-C, dissuading the latter from using Mew as setup fodder. A Mild nature helps Mew exert as much pressure as possible with Ice Beam and Flamethrower, while a Hasty nature most notably lets it outspeed Hydreigon and Speed tie Zapdos. Magic Guard negates chip damage from Life Orb and entry hazards, helping Mew stay healthy for longer and allowing it to better utilize its natural bulk to come into play. Sheer Force is an alternative particularly if Mew is used alongside a teammate with Magic Guard, such as Hisuian Electrode. It greatly increases Mew's power, notably letting it OHKO Garchomp and Iron Treads and pressure otherwise solid checks such as Meloetta, at the cost of its longevity. Bulky pivots such as Corviknight, Quaquaval, Iron Treads, and Meloetta can take on fast threats to Mew such as Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Iron Moth and switch Mew in safely. Fast offensive pivots such as Meowscarada and Sandy Shocks are also strong partners that can give Mew opportunities to come into play and clean up late-game after it softens up their checks. Garchomp and Ting-Lu can set entry hazards to help Mew break down its checks over time.

Skarmory.comments:
Other Options

Skarmory can make use of Flame Body or Static to fish for burn or paralysis on Pokemon that commonly make contact with it, such as Roaring Moon, Great Tusk, and Corviknight. Specially defensive variants of Skarmory with max Special Defense instead of Defense can run Water Absorb to better check Manaphy and Ogerpon-W or Volt Absorb to reliably check Zapdos and Sandy Shocks.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Skarmory's low HP and Special Defense leave it quite weak to special attackers like Gholdengo, Primarina, and Deoxys-S.

Fire-types: If Skarmory isn't using Well-Baked Body, it struggles against Fire-types like Ceruledge, Cinderace, and Ogerpon-H.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Zapdos, Iron Hands, and Sandy Shocks as well as Hadron Engine users like Latios and Deoxys-S can reliably outspeed and threaten an OHKO on Skarmory without Volt Absorb.

Physical Wall.description:
Thanks to its high Defense stat, solid utility movepool, and amazing typing, Skarmory functions as a physically defensive wall as well as an entry hazard setter. Fluffy lets Skarmory better check strong physical attackers such as Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Kingambit, whereas Intimidate allows it to check Chien-Pao and the Ogerpon formes excluding Ogerpon-H; alternatively, Well-Baked Body enables Skarmory to check Fire-types like Moltres, Ogerpon-H, and Iron Moth lacking Discharge. Body Press hits Steel-types like Heatran, Iron Treads, and Kingambit for a great deal of damage, while Brave Bird is slightly stronger than an unboosted Body Press and nails Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and the Ogerpon formes. Spikes is very useful on hazard stacking team archetypes and can quickly wear down Great Tusk, Manaphy, and Swampert, whereas Stealth Rock gives Skarmory valuable role compression and wears down Chien-Pao and Corviknight. Whirlwind works well in conjunction with Spikes to wear down the opposing team quite fast and forces out setup sweepers like Bulk Up Great Tusk and Iron Defense Zamazenta, while Iron Defense, which should only be used with Body Press, is a move that lets Skarmory set up along with setup sweepers like Zamazenta, Kingambit, and Great Tusk. Otherwise, Taunt can be used to prevent Corviknight from using Defog or Roost as well as Ting-Lu from setting up Spikes or Stealth Rock, Heavily punishing both. Leftovers gives Skarmory extra longevity against Pokemon like Zamazenta, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit, though Rocky Helmet can be used instead to punish Pokemon like Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Zamazenta. Heavy-Duty Boots grants Skarmory immunity to Stealth Rock chip, which is quite helpful when it needs to repeatably switch in with Stealth Rock up.

Skarmory functions on more defensively focused teams that tend to slowly wear down the opposing team with Spikes. Partners like Roaring Moon, Zapdos, and Gholdengo appreciate the entry hazards that Skarmory sets up, as it allows them to slowly wear down their checks, like Great Tusk, Swampert, and Manaphy. Skarmory struggles with the tier's many special attackers, so specially defensive teammates like Iron Treads, Swampert, and RegenVest Roaring Moon are much appreciated. Depending on its ability, Skarmory will need teammates to help it on the physical side. If Skarmory is not using Fluffy, Pecharunt is a nice partner to aid against Choice Band Zamazenta, while physically defensive Manaphy can help against Chien-Pao for non-Intimidate Skarmory. Lastly, Skarmory without Well-Baked Body very much appreciates a Fire-resistant or Fire-immune partner like Swampert or Primordial Sea Zapdos. A Ghost-type Pokemon like Pecharunt or Earth Eater Gholdengo works as a great partner for Skarmory, as it can prevent Great Tusk and Iron Treads from using Rapid Spin to remove the entry hazards that Skarmory sets up.

Sticky Web.description: Smeargle functions incredibly as an entry hazard lead on hyper offense teams thanks to its ability to lay Sticky Web and Stealth Rock via Stone Axe. Taunt can prevent hazards from Deoxys-D and Skarmory and sweepers such as Ogerpon-W and Gholdengo from setting up, while Memento can allow safe switch-ins for other frail Pokemon like Gengar and Chien-Pao. Smeargle is exclusively used on hyper offense teams due to it more or less being a suicide lead. Some notable partners include frail attackers such as Swords Dance Iron Boulder and Sheer Force Gengar, which benefit greatly from Sticky Web and the safe switch-in Memento provides. Some counters to Smeargle include Kingambit and Chien-Pao, since they are both immune to Taunt and Memento, enabling them to use it as setup fodder; as a result, Fighting-types such as offensive Bulk Up Great Tusk and Iron Hands are good partners. Another Pokemon that annoys Smeargle is Great Tusk due to its hazard removal capabilities, making threats such as Polteageist, Ogerpon-C, and Tail Glow Manaphy much appreciated.

Special Wall.description: Blissey is a decent, albeit niche, wall and utility Pokemon in AAA with its ability to check most special attackers and extremely diverse movepool. Seismic Toss allows Blissey to not be completely passive and gives it consistent damage. Blissey's last two moveslots are flexible. Calm Mind + Shadow Ball is enough to beat the few special attackers that can otherwise defeat Blissey one-on-one such as Sheer Force Gengar and Gholdengo. Stealth Rock provides entry hazard support to free up a moveslot for a teammate, while Thunder Wave spreads status, crippling Pokemon like Azelf and Manaphy, and Heal Bell allows Blissey to operate as a cleric. Unaware allows Blissey to check special attackers attempting to set up on it like Gholdengo, Tail Glow Manaphy, and Iron Moth, while Well-Baked Body allows it to check Iron Moth while also giving it a more favorable matchup into Volcarona and Heatran. Magic Guard allows Blissey to avoid chip damage from entry hazards, letting it function as a better wall. Blissey most commonly runs Leftovers, as the extra healing can be extremely helpful, although on teams with more shaky hazard control, Heavy-Duty Boots can be opted for instead. A Calm nature is used to make Blissey function better as a special wall, notiably allowing it to always avoid the 2HKO from Sheer Force Gengar's Focus Blast. Blissey is most notably a special wall that does not require the use of Regenerator, which allows physical walls such as Great Tusk to run it instead. Blissey is most commonly seen on stall and fat team structures. Physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Deoxys-D are a must, as they help deal with Blissey's weakness to physical attackers and make a potent defensive core with it.

Wallbreaker.description: Choice Specs Latios is a fearsome wallbreaker that can force progress in almost every matchup with its combination of powerful STAB attacks, effectively mixed coverage with Psyshock, and ability to finesse poor matchups with Flip Turn and Trick. Adaptability Luster Purge consistently OHKOes common slower offensive Pokemon like Zapdos without dropping Latios's Special Attack, but Trick can cripple an opposing Chansey or Deoxys-D or disrupt a setup sweeper like Cresselia. Adaptability provides the most overall power to the set, letting it reliably 2HKO common RegenVest pivots like Swampert and Manaphy with Psyshock, while Tinted Lens lets it 2HKO Meloetta and Empoleon with Psyshock and have a good chance to OHKO Corviknight and Gholdengo with Draco Meteor. Latios pairs well with fast cleaners like Deoxys-S and Hisuian Electrode, as they can readily take advantage of the opposing RegenVest user being removed from the match. Strong physical wallbreakers like Iron Boulder and the Ogerpon formes appreciate Latios bringing them in safely with Flip Turn and even chunking their checks like Corviknight that may try to eat a predicted Psyshock. Latios invites in powerful Dark-type revenge killers like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao, making robust checks to these such as Fluffy Corviknight and Regenerator Primarina mandatory. Latios functions best with frequent entry to the field, making entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Great Tusk excellent partners. Slow pivots like Corviknight and Deoxys-D can help get it onto the field safely.

Speed Control.description: Choice Scarf Latios is a reliable source of speed control and offensive pivot that sets itself apart from Azelf with its powerful Draco Meteor. Psyshock allows Latios to effectively have mixed coverage and 2HKO common RegenVest pivots like Swampert and Manaphy after Spikes, while Luster Purge is notably stronger against common offensive Pokemon like Hisuian Electrode, Cinderace, and Barraskewda and is more spammable than Draco Meteor. Adaptability is more consistent, as it is always active and does not announce itself, while Hadron Engine can support Electric-types and Surge Surfer users, disrupt opposing terrain from the likes of Azelf and Deoxys-S, and let Latios OHKO Corviknight with Thunderbolt. Trick is an option in the last slot to shut down bulky setup sweepers like Cresselia and cripple walls like Deoxys-D. Latios works best with slow pivots like Corviknight and Swampert that can get it onto the field in advantageous positions; similarly, Latios often provides easy entry to slow, wallbreaking teammates like Galarian Zapdos and Ceruledge with Flip Turn. Latios is heavily threatened by Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon, as they discourage it from using its Psychic-type moves and can even threaten it thanks to priority moves and Choice Scarf, respectively. Physically defensive Manaphy and Fluffy Corviknight, respectively, can provide insurance against these threats.

Calm Mind.description: Latios leverages a good Speed tier, sky-high Special Attack, and Calm Mind to be one of the tier's most dangerous wallbreakers and sweepers. Psyshock greatly threatens common RegenVest users such as Swampert, Manaphy, and Meloetta. Recover provides additional longevity, allowing Latios to switch in against foes such as Heatran and Pecharunt and threaten to wallbreak multiple times in a single game. Calm Mind allows Latios to set up against passive foes such as Corviknight and Skarmory. Soul Dew notably makes Adaptability Draco Meteor a guaranteed 2HKO on Corviknight after a Calm Mind, but Leftovers is an option to give Latios more longevity. Adaptability is the preferred ability for consistent high damage, allowing Latios to reliably 2HKO Blissey and RegenVest Swampert with Psyshock, while Tinted Lens is an option to threaten an OHKO on Corviknight and Gholdengo with Draco Meteor after a Calm Mind and 2HKO Heatran and Hisuian Goodra with Psyshock after a boost. Latios works fantastically with other powerful special attackers such as Iron Moth, Zapdos, and Azelf, as they all appreciate RegenVest users and Blissey being weakened. Latios also appreciates slow, physically bulky pivots such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and physically defensive Manaphy, who which can both pivot it in safely and effectively check the offensive Dark-types that threaten Latios such as Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, and Chien-Pao. Latios also appreciates the aforementioned Corviknight and Mandibuzz, along with Great Tusk, for their consistent entry hazard removal, allowing it to enter the field and frequently threaten the foe.

RegenVest.description: Jirachi sets itself apart from other RegenVest pivots by better checking the prevalent, powerful Psychic-types—Latios, Deoxys-S, Scream Tail, and Azelf—and providing Future Sight support to powerful physical wallbreakers like Zamazenta, Chien-Pao, and Ceruledge. Many of the best physical walls such as Corviknight and Manaphy survive by barely avoiding 2HKOs, which they fail to when switching into Future Sight as well, while others like Iron Hands, Great Tusk, and Pecharunt take far too much damage from Future Sight anyway. Doom Desire is an alternative with no immunities that also hits Scream Tail harder but otherwise has worse coverage against relevant targets. Psychic Noise denies recovery to Empoleon and Corviknight and punishes aggressive Iron Moth and Great Tusk switch ins. The last moveslot is extremely flexible; Thunderbolt for Corviknight, Iron Head for Scream Tail, Ice Punch for Dragonite, and Body Slam to fish for paralysis are some of the most notable options. Jirachi should be paired with physical wallbreakers on more offensive teams, as they best take advantage of its combination of slow pivoting and Future Sight. Fighting-types like Iron Hands and Zamazenta, Ceruledge, and the Ogerpon formes are excellent teammates that also appreciate Jirachi switching into fast Psychic-types like Deoxys-S and Azelf attempting to revenge kill them. Jirachi is weak to several common special attackers, most notably primal weather users like Iron Moth and Primarina, and Ghost-types such as Gengar and Gholdengo, so teammates that can offensively check them like other primal weather users and Roaring Moon are greatly appreciated. Since Jirachi is wholly dependent on Regenerator for recovery, it appreciates entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight to maximize that recovery.

Defensive.description: Boasting high defensive stats and a plethora of utility moves, Deoxys-D makes for an excellent Unaware wall that can check Iron Hands and setup Great Tusk while also providing additional utility like setting entry hazards and pivoting. Spikes is the preferred hazard, as Deoxys-D can usually set multiple layers, but Stealth Rock is an alternative for teams that lack a Stealth Rock setter otherwise, and Knock Off can be used to limit opposing setup threats like Iron Boulder and Quaquaval while also debilitating walls like Corviknight and Swampert. Teleport can be used in conjunction with Deoxys-D's low Speed to safely switch Pokemon in, while Thunder Wave can be used to cripple Iron Boulder and Dragonite. Leftovers is the preferred item for extra longevity, but Heavy-Duty Boots is an option on Teleport sets to enable easier pivoting. On teams that do not need setup control, Fluffy and Intimidate dramatically increase its physical bulk versus key targets like Iron Boulder. Defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Mandibuzz appreciate Deoxys-D being able to take on setup threats such as Iron Hands and Iron Boulder, allowing them to better handle Dark-types like Roaring Moon. Offensive Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos, Chien-Pao, and Ceruledge appreciate Deoxys-D being able to weaken opposing walls with hazards or Knock Off, as well as potentially getting them in safely if it's running Teleport. Deoxys-D narrowly avoids 2HKOs from stronger wallbreakers like Iron Boulder, so hazard control options like Scrappy Great Tusk and Corviknight are highly recommended so that Deoxys-D can have more longevity.

All-Out Attacker.description:
Deoxys-S leverages its colorful offensive movepool to become a formidable wallbreaker and, alongside its superb Speed tier, potentially clean late-game as well. Psychic works well with Sheer Force variants, but Psycho Boost can be used when going with Hadron Engine; the former's reliability and spammability can be forgone for the latter's immediate sheer power, reaching feats such as straight up OHKOing the Ogerpon formes, Moltres, and potentially Garganacl. Ice Beam reliably hits Latios and otherwise problematic Dark-types like Roaring Moon, Ting-Lu, Meowscarada, and Mandibuzz super effectively while additionally being capable of OHKOing Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Zapdos without suffering Psycho Boost drops, especially since the last two can withstand a Psychic. Thunderbolt hits non-Volt Absorb Empoleon and Corviknight, while Energy Ball handles RegenVest Swampert, with either move covering for RegenVest Manaphy and Primarina. Focus Blast hits Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra, Heatran, non-Bulletproof Empoleon, and Kingambit and pressures Dark-types like Roaring Moon and Ting-Lu better than Ice Beam, notably OHKOing the former and potentially the latter. Shadow Ball deals with non-Bullet Proof Gholdengo and Scream Tail. Sheer Force works well in tandem with Life Orb, keeping Deoxys-S healthy to repeatedly wallbreak. On top of the slightly higher power boost, Hadron Engine is an alternative that trades longevity for Electric Terrain-boosted Thunderbolts; notably, it makes sure that the move can OHKO physically defensive Corviknight and Mandibuzz, has significant odds to 2HKO even specially defensive RegenVest Manaphy, and is strong enough to 2HKO Scream Tail after minor chip damage and defensive Gholdengo, especially Bulletproof variants of the latter.

Deoxys-S finds a home on bulky offense and offense teams that appreciate its wallbreaking and cleaning prowess. Slow defensive pivots like Swampert, Manaphy, and Corviknight are valuable supporting pieces; aside from bringing Deoxys-S into the field safely, they can switch into and check Choice Scarf and priority users like Roaring Moon, Latios, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit looking to revenge kill it. Additionally, Swampert and Manaphy can use Knock Off to make opposing RegenVest users like Manaphy and Swampert easier for Deoxys-S to break down, while Corviknight provides entry hazard removal to let Deoxys-S come in repeatedly. Other hazard removal options include Great Tusk and Iron Treads; the former can also check Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon that can revenge kill Deoxys-S, while the latter switches into Gholdengo and Scream Tail if Deoxys-S lacks the appropriate coverage to threaten them. Offensive pivots like Roaring Moon, Cinderace, and Meowscarada are similarly useful to bring Deoxys-S in safely, as they tend to invite in physical walls like Great Tusk, Pecharunt, and Skarmory that it feasts on. What they lack in defensive profile is made up for by their ability to pressure common Deoxys-S checks like Gholdengo, Heatran, and RegenVest Swampert, especially if it lacks the corresponding coverage; other physical wallbreakers like Zamazenta and Chien-Pao are thus similarly helpful in this regard. These offensive threats can also overwhelm shared checks in Scream Tail, Ting-Lu, and Mandibuzz together with Deoxys-S, letting either of them take over the game more easily. Entry hazards from setters like Garchomp, Heatran, and Great Tusk can take advantage of the switches Deoxys-S forces and are great at chipping down its checks, namely the RegenVest users that cannot afford Heavy-Duty Boots.

Double Dance.description: Garchomp is a great cleaner and sweeper on offensive teams thanks to its excellent Attack, good bulk, and high-Base Power moves, and it has the ability to outspeed common offensive threats after a Scale Shot such as Iron Boulder, Zamazenta, and Roaring Moon. Stone Edge threatens Flying-types like Mandibuzz and Zapdos and hits Corviknight decently hard, and after using Swords Dance, Garchomp can OHKO offensive Great Tusk with Earthquake and 2HKO Fluffy Corviknight with Stone Edge. Life Orb gives Garchomp a decent chance of 2HKOing Corviknight at +1 and guarantees the OHKO on Choice Band Zamazenta at +2, while Loaded Dice offers more consistency to Scale Shot and avoids recoil from Life Orb. An Adamant nature lets Garchino 2HKO Unaware Scream Tail and Deoxys-D with Life Orb, while a Jolly nature lets it outspeed Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Modest Deoxys-S after a Scale Shot. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Zamazenta appreciate Garchomp's cleaning ability once it gets set up; in return, they can help chip walls like Deoxys-D and Corviknight that it can struggle to break through, giving it an easier time cleaning. Garchomp's only decent Speed prior to setting up leaves it vulnerable to being KOed by threats like Latios and Roaring Moon, so teammates that can check them on hyper offense teams like Gholdengo and Zamazenta, respectively, are appreciated. Even after setup, faster Pokemon like Choice Scarf Azelf and priority users like Dragonite can threaten massive damage on Garchomp, making teammates that can deal with them like Roaring Moon and Gholdengo, respectively, good partners.

Magic Guard.description: Lucario's niche lies in its great mixed wallbreaking capacity and amazing STAB combination, with Close Combat and Steel Beam hitting the majority of the metagame for good damage and potentially 2HKOing them. Earthquake deals with Toxapex, Dark Pulse smacks Gholdengo, and Stone Edge prevents Zapdos and Iron Moth from switching in safely. Nasty Plot lets it muscle through bulky teams that try to dance around its coverage moves. An alternative EV spread of 252 Atk / 4 SpA / 252 Spe can be used to deal more damage on the physical side. Lucario's excellent wallbreaking abilities make fast offensive partners like Roaring Moon, Deoxys-S, and Chien-Pao good partners, as they can clean up after it has broken holes into the opposing team. Lucario's lack of defensive utility makes walls like Corviknight, RegenVest Manaphy, and Swampert much appreciated; additionally, they can bring it back onto the field with a slow pivot. Lucario greatly struggles with four-moveslot syndrome, so teammates that can deal with Zapdos and Iron Moth like RegenVest or Magic Guard Roaring Moon when not using Stone Edge and teammates that can switch into Gholdengo like Swampert when not running Dark Pulse are appreciated.

Unaware.description: Cresselia's titanic bulk and access to Calm Mind allow it to pose a major threat to the opponent's team, turning other setup sweepers into fodder. It can also leverage its Psychic typing to check huge threats such as Azelf and Deoxys-S. Late game, Cresselia can function as a terrifying and offbeat set-up sweeper, boosting and using Moonblast to hit Dark-types such as Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon. Cresselia's ideal opportunity to set up is in front of passive walls like Manaphy, Swampert, and non-Unaware Blissey. Cresselia's best teammates are Pokemon that can take on Dark-Type moves like Corviknight and Great Tusk. Prankster Corviknight and Deoxys-S can set dual screens to make Cresselia's setup easier. Cresselia also appreciates teammates such as Mandibuzz, Blissey, and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra that can switch into Ghost-types.

Manaphy.comments:
Other Options

Level 99 Manaphy is a tempting option, guaranteeing a slower U-turn against opposing standard RegenVest Manaphy, but it is generally not worth having an overall less bulky Manaphy. RegenVest Manaphy can afford to use a different EV spread than the maximized ones here if looking to survive specific rolls. A physically defensive set with 200 Speed EVs may be considered to outspeed and better check Great Tusk, but it is usually not worth losing the slower U-turn or the extra bulk investment. Dazzling Gleam is interchangeable with Alluring Voice; the former checks Throat Chop Roaring Moon, and the latter dissuades setup sweepers and hits Substitute users. Psychic is an option in the final moveslot to dissuade Iron Moth and Pecharunt from switching in while still hitting Zamazenta, whereas Ice Beam can be used to hit Zapdos and Desolate Land Landorus, but the other options are generally considered better. Alternatively, a physically defensive Regenerator set with Rocky Helmet and Take Heart is an option to act as a bulky wincon while still checking physical attackers, but this Manaphy set is easily forced out by special attackers without a boost and may struggle to find setup opportunities. Tail Glow sets may consider running Primordial Sea and Weather Ball for the additional power and being able to hit Desolate Land users, but this set becomes extremely slow and easier to switch around or pressure out. Tail Glow sets can also consider running Scald, trading some damage for additional utility and the chance to burn something before fainting, but the drop in power isn't worth sacrificing for. Hydro Pump is another option on these sets for additional power, notably 3HKOing Empoleon after a Tail Glow boost, but the reduced PP and accuracy is usually not worth it. Alternatively, hyper offense teams can run a potent set with Fluffy, Unaware, or an immunity ability alongside Take Heart, Acid Armor, and Stored Power to muscle through checks like even opposing RegenVest users, Heatran, and Empoleon after enough boosts.

Checks and Counters

Electric-type Moves: Zapdos, Sandy Shocks, and Pokemon with Electric-type moves like Deoxys-S, Latios, and Gholdengo are often able to muscle through non-Motor Drive Manaphy even with an Assault Vest and maximum Special Defense investment.

Desolate Land Users: Aside from Knock Off, most Manaphy sets lack any effective tools against Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Moltres, and Heatran, giving them free switch-in opportunities to either set up entry hazards or threaten Manaphy with Solar Beam.

Grass-types: Even the most physically defensive Manaphy sets can't reliably deal with Meowscarada or the Ogerpon formes, and Hisuian Electrode is a major annoyance for any spread.

Passive Damage: Without Take Heart, Manaphy is extremely vulnerable to passive damage in the form of Toxic from Iron Moth, Pecharunt, or Mandibuzz. Likewise, Manaphy is worn down extremely quickly by entry hazards set by the likes of Great Tusk, Skarmory, and Scream Tail.

RegenVest.description:
Manaphy leverages a great defensive typing, solid mixed bulk, and incredible utility moves including the coveted Scald to be among the tier's premier RegenVest users. Manaphy is able to comfortably switch in and scout dangerous special attackers like Scream Tail, Azelf, and Gholdengo and, when running the more physically bulky spread, powerful wallbreakers like Chien-Pao, Cinderace, and Great Tusk. Knock Off is notable for threatening decent damage against Gholdengo and removing key items like Assault Vest and Heavy-Duty Boots from would-be switch-ins like opposing Manaphy, Iron Moth, and Moltres. While obviously used for slow pivoting, U-turn is also able to threaten an OHKO on Meowscarada, which would otherwise switch in easily. Alluring Voice is the most common final move for its ability to threaten Latios, Zamazenta, and non-Throat Chop Roaring Moon, but Energy Ball is an option to smack opposing Manaphy, Swampert, and Primarina. An EV spread with full Defense investment is the most common spread, turning Manaphy into a potent mixed wall that can check Cinderace, Great Tusk, and non-Choice Band Roaring Moon while still acting as a solid secondary check to special wallbreakers like Deoxys-S, Primarina, and Gholdengo; it can also choose to run a full Special Defense-invested set to more solidly check these nuclear special attackers.

RegenVest Manaphy is renowned for being able to sturdy up the defensive backbone of almost any team style, but balance and bulky offense teams tend to benefit the most from its presence. Manaphy is excellent at taking hits from powerful wallbreakers like Roaring Moon, Primarina, and Gholdengo and pivoting out with U-turn, so frail wallbreakers like Chien-Pao, Sandy Shocks, and Deoxys-S naturally appreciate its ability to eat a hit then bring them in damage-free. Similarly, Manaphy can be an asset to slower wallbreakers like Gholdengo and Primarina that appreciate its hit-taking capability. Corviknight is the most classic pairing with Manaphy, with both defensive and specially defensive sets able to shore up Manaphy's less-invested stat. If running physically defensive Manaphy, a sturdier check to powerful Choice Band users like Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Meowscarada is necessary; consider Skarmory, Great Tusk, or especially Pecharunt as a teammate. Similarly, any RegenVest Manaphy set appreciates a Steel-type special wall like Heatran, Iron Treads, or specially defensive Gholdengo that can help versus threats like Zapdos, Sheer Force Deoxys-S, and Latios. Manaphy is especially vulnerable to getting worn down by entry hazards and being overwhelmed by foes if it loses its Assault Vest, so hazard removers like Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Great Tusk are mandatory teammates, with the latter two doubling as Knock Off absorbers.

Tail Glow.description:
Tail Glow Manaphy is a decent setup sweeper, utilizing Tail Glow to boost its mediocre Special Attack to staggering numbers. Alluring Voice smacks Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Latios while being Manaphy's best move against Meowscarada. Energy Ball allows Manaphy to beat its Water-type checks in RegenVest Swampert, Primarina, and opposing Manaphy, while Psychic invalidates Desolate Land Iron Moth from being a check. Protosynthesis + Booster Energy grants Manaphy a one-time Speed boost, preventing would-be revenge killers in Roaring Moon, Scream Tail, and Zamazenta from forcing it out. Surge Surfer allows Manaphy to gain a greater Speed boost, allowing it to outspeed even Choice Scarf users like Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, and Azelf while electric terrain is active at the caveat of requiring teammates with Hadron Engine. Electric Seed makes it harder to revenge kill Manaphy when using Surge Surfer, while Life Orb boosts Manaphy's damage output. Motor Drive allows Manaphy to surprise and turn the tables on Electric-types like Sandy Shocks and Regieleki and gain a free Speed boost, trading in consistency for the potential of multiple activations and defensive utility.

Tail Glow Manaphy fits best on hyper offensive teams due to their nature of being fast-paced and possessing strong setup sweepers. Although Manaphy has immense damage potential, it is unable to muscle past counters like RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, Desolate Land Heatran, and if not using Psychic, Iron Moth. Thus, teammates who can threaten them and use them as setup fodder pair well with Manaphy, making IronPress Zamazenta, Dragon Dance Roaring Moon, and Double Dance Iron Crown good partners. Manaphy also appreciates dedicated leads that hyper offense teams employ, like Ribombee and Dual Screens Corviknight; the former shutting down revenge killing attempts from foes like Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Azelf, which would outspeed Manaphy even after a Speed boost, and the latter allowing Manaphy to set up safely, allowing it to brute force its way through the opposing team. When using Surge Surfer, Manaphy should always be paired with teammates that use Hadron Engine like Sandy Shocks and Latios.

Choice Band.description: Hisuian Samurott is a decent wallbreaker due to Adaptability, Choice Band, and a great STAB combination that also pressures the ever-present Corviknight to choose between recovery and Defogging. Ceaseless Edge is a versatile move that deals good damage to foes while also setting up Spikes, helping Hisuian Samurott's teammates or even itself to pick off chipped foes later in the game. Knock Off provides utility by removing items from switch-ins such as Corviknight and Quaquaval. Sucker Punch is a good priority move that lets Hisuian Samurott deal heavy damage to faster foes such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Zapdos. Brick Break can be used instead to deal with dual screens leads such as Corviknight and Mew. Hisuian Samurott's ability to set up Spikes and pester defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Scream Tail by removing their items is appreciated by various offensive teammates such as Chien-Pao and Galarian Zapdos that can take advantage of chipped foes. Fluffy and Intimidate Quaquaval wall Hisuian Samurott very easily, so spinblockers such as Desolate Land Skeledirge and Ceruledge are good partners as they can pressure Quaquaval and block it from removing Spikes set by Hisuian Samurott. Hisuian Samurott is susceptible to getting revenge killed due to low Speed and bulk, so robust walls such as Corviknight and Meloetta that can pivot and provide safe switch in opportunities to it are appreciated.

Swords Dance.description: After a Swords Dance boost, Hisuian Samurott becomes a terrifying wallbreaker that can dent physically defensive walls like Corviknight. Sucker Punch acts as speed control against Pokemon like Zapdos and Iron Moth. Ceaseless Edge forces defensive Pokemon, such as Corviknight, to switch in and choose between entry hazard removal or healing. Black Glasses is the item of choice, boosting its Dark-type moves without the recoil of Life Orb. Pokemon like Thundurus and Iron Moth are very useful teammates, as they compensate for Hisuian Samurott's average Speed tier and can heavily damage physical walls that counter Hisuian Samurott like Quaquaval and Zamazenta-C. In return, Hisuian Samurott wears down special walls with its ability to set up a layer of Spikes. Additionally, due to its unimpressive bulk, Hisuian Samurott relies on walls such as Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra to compensate for the lack of defensive utility it brings.

Sheer Force.description: Hisuian Zoroark serves as a threatening sweeper and wallbreaker thanks to its great Special Attack, good Speed, and incredible moveset. Body Slam allows Hisuian Zoroark to hit specially defensive walls such as Manaphy, Swampert, and Meloetta. Focus Blast hits foes like Hisuian Goodra, Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, Blissey, and Mandibuzz. Knock Off allows Hisuian Zoroark to remove crucial items like Manaphy's and Swampert's Assault Vests and Mandibuzz's Heavy-Duty Boots, helping it and its teammates break through these Pokemon and allowing it to be more self sufficient, as it does not rely on teammates to get rid of said items. Psychic is an alternative option that dents Iron Hands, Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Iron Moth. Sheer Force lets Hisuian Zoroark hit harder to achieve feats such as 2HKOing non-Unaware Mandibuzz. A Timid nature should be used on sets with Nasty Plot, as a higher Attack is not needed. Teammates such as Iron Moth and Azelf appreciate Hisuian Zoroark's ability to force chip damage on special walls such as RegenVest Manaphy and Meloetta. Hisuian Zoroark is very frail, leaving it prone to revenge killing attempts from revenge killers like Roaring Moon and Azelf, so it appreciates slow pivots like Corviknight and Manaphy that can help it switch in safely. Hisuian Zoroark appreciates entry hazard setters like Great Tusk and Deoxys-D, as they can help chip walls that would otherwise beat it.

Magic Guard.description: Hisuian Zoroark finds a niche on semi-stall and offensive teams as a progress maker or as an offensive pivot with its wide variety of utility options and ability to ignore passive damage thanks to Magic Guard. Knock Off cripples special walls by depraving RegenVest users such as Manaphy and Swampert of their Assault Vests or by limiting Blissey's, Empoleon's, and Mandibuzz's longevity by removing their Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots, allowing Hisuian Zoroark or teammates like Iron Moth and Azelf to break past them later in the game. Will-O-Wisp further weakens these special walls, forcing them to be worn down over time and notably enabling Hisuian Zoroark's Hex to break past them; it also cripples physical threats like Great Tusk and Iron Hands. U-turn allows Hisuian Zoroark to generate free momentum for its team while forcing its switch-ins to take chip damage from entry hazards as it pivots out, whereas Taunt denies Blissey and Empoleon recovery. Hisuian Zoroark should be paired with offensive entry hazard setters like Sandy Shocks, Pixilate Scream Tail, and Galvanize Kommo-o that can keep up the pressure on hazard removers to maximize its ability to wear the opposing team down over time. Sturdy checks to offensive threats that force Hisuian Zoroark out like Roaring Moon, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Azelf are needed, so good teammates that can stave them off like Great Tusk and Empoleon are recommended.

Mandibuzz is a solid physical wall with high defensive stats, a useful typing, and valuable utility moves in Defog, Toxic, and Knock Off. Magic Guard circumvents its normally crippling Stealth Rock weakness, letting it act as an excellent Knock Off absorber from the likes of Roaring Moon and Meowscarda, as well as a status absorber from Toxapex, Pecharunt, and opposing Mandibuzz. Foul Play allows Mandibuzz to beat physical setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Ceruledge, while Knock Off can limit the longevity of defensive walls and remove Assault Vests, enabling special attacking teammates like Primarina, Latios, and Azelf. Toxic can cripple walls such as Swampert and Scream Tail and shuts down bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Scream Tail and Bulk Up Great Tusk. Defog provides valuable entry hazard control, especially for Stealth Rock-weak wallbreakers Chien-Pao, Ceruledge, and Ogerpon-H, which Mandibuzz can also slow pivot in with U-turn alongside 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature. Leftovers provides passive healing that can't be mitigated by indirect damage, while Rocky Helmet punishes contact moves, most notably U-turn from Corviknight and Roaring Moon. Mandibuzz naturally loses to many of the tier's common physical attackers, including Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-C, exacerbated by the fact that it lacks a true defensive ability or immunity; other physically defensive walls such as Corviknight and Toxapex help shore up these weaknesses. Although Mandibuzz can be an emergency switch-in to Psychic-types like Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Latios, it should generally not be relied on due to its uninvested special bulk and their various super effective coverage moves. Therefore, Mandibuzz appreciates specially defensive walls, such as Empoleon, Manaphy, and Swampert, to check the previously mentioned special attackers along with Gengar and Primarina.

Nasty Plot.description: Hydreigon possesses a niche as an extremely potent wallbreaker, as Nasty Plot distinguishes Hydreigon amongst fellow wallbreakers like Latios and Deoxys-S by threatening to OHKO RegenVest Swampert and Manaphy. Flash Cannon chunks Scream Tail attempting to switch into a Draco Meteor; Focus Blast provides a strong option that smacks Steel-types like Kingambit, Iron Treads, and Heatran; and Earth Power provides a weaker but more reliable option to hit those aforementioned Steel-types. With a Modest nature, Hydreigon threatens to OHKO non-Unaware Blissey after slight chip and guarantees the OHKO on the aforementioned RegenVest Swampert and Manaphy with Draco Meteor after a Nasty Plot. A Timid nature can be considered to outspeed Great Tusk and remove the risk of Jolly Ceruledge and Timid Archaludon winning the speed tie. Hydreigon's low Speed and lack of good defensive utility mean that faster threats like Chien-Pao, Zamazenta, and Scream Tail force it out, making teammates like Corviknight, RegenVest Manaphy, and Swampert good partners on balance teams; alternatively, Sticky Web support from Ribombee and Smeargle is much appreciated on hyper offense teams, preventing would-be revenge killers like Zamazenta and Barraskewda from outspeeding it, which invalidates their ability to revenge kill it. Other special wallbreakers like Volcarona, Deoxys-S, and Gengar appreciate Hydreigon's ability to break holes in a team's defensive core, allowing them to clean up later in the game. Fairy-types like Primarina and, to a lesser extent, Scream Tail can check Hydreigon with ease, so teammates that can threaten them like Hisuian Electrode, Ogerpon-C, and Ceruledge are greatly appreciated.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Terrakion is a fearsome wallbreaker thanks to its good Attack stat, useful offensive typing, high-Base Power STAB moves, and ability to bypass Fluffy. Earthquake allows Terrakion to hit non-Earth Eater Gholdengo and have a slightly stronger and more accurate option against foes like Iron Hands and Pecharunt. Terrakion's last moveslot is very flexible, as it likes to use Close Combat or Stone Edge almost all of the time. Stealth Rock can help wear down the opposing team and chip would-be defensive checks into range of a 2HKO, while Quick Attack can pick off faster, weakened foes, and Poison Jab does more damage to Primarina and Scream Tail. Teammates such as Iron Boulder, Zamazenta, and Roaring Moon appreciate Terrakion's ability to break through Corviknight, which is one of their biggest roadblocks, and can clean up weakened teams. Terrakion is vulnerable to being revenge killed due to its middling Speed stat, so a strong defensive backbone featuring Pokemon like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Manaphy is recommended. Terrakion fits best on balance and bulky offense teams that need a wallbreaker and can help it switch in safely, so slow pivots like the aforementioned Corviknight and Manaphy make for good teammates. Additionally, special pivots like Azelf and Hisuian Electrode can get it in on special walls such as RegenVest Meloetta and Hisuian Goodra, which it can threaten out.

Nasty Plot.description: Thanks to Thundurus's wide variety of coverage, access to Nasty Plot, and high Speed that allows it to outspeed Iron Moth and the Ogerpon formes, it functions as a hard-hitting sweeper. Nasty Plot further boosts Thundurus's high Special Attack, allowing it to OHKO Scream Tail, defensive Gholdengo, and RegenVest Manaphy at +2, while Knock Off can be used on Magic Guard sets to remove Assault Vest from Hisuian Goodra, Meloetta, and Iron Hands. Focus Blast gives Thundurus super effective coverage against Roaring Moon, Heatran, and Volt Absorb Empoleon. Psychic enables Thundurus to hit Iron Hands, Great Tusk, and Landorus; alternatively, Grass Knot consistently 2HKOes Ting-Lu and Swampert while still OHKOing Great Tusk, at the cost of Sheer Force sets taking Life Orb recoil. Sheer Force avoids Life Orb chip damage and boosts Thundurus's power, allowing it to 2HKO Deoxys-D and max HP Scream Tail after Stealth Rock, while Magic Guard also avoids Life Orb damage and chip damage from Stealth Rock. Thundurus struggles to sweep opposing teams possessing fast revenge killers such as Roaring Moon, Azelf, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo; therefore, it requires allies like Corviknight and Empoleon that easily switch into these threats and pivot it in. Fast special attacking pivots such as Azelf and Iron Moth appreciate Thundurus's ability to wallbreak, as it allows them to clean more easily.

Bolstering an incredible Special Attack stat combined with a great movepool makes Thundurus-T an extremely threatening wallbreaker. Focus Blast nails foes such as Hisuian Goodra, Volt Absorb Empoleon, and Volt Absorb Corviknight. Psychic hits Great Tusk and Iron Hands, while Grass Knot can let Thundurus-T lure in and take out Swampert while still hitting Great Tusk for super effective damage. Nasty Plot boosts Thundurus-T's Special Attack to nuclear levels, allowing it to OHKO Hisuian Goodra and Blissey with Focus Blast after slight chip damage. Fast specially offensive pivots such as Iron Moth, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Latios appreciate Thundurus-T's incredible wallbreaking power, as they can take advantage of weakened special walls such as Swampert, Manaphy, and Meloetta. Thundurus-T loves slow, defensive pivots such as Corviknight, physically defensive Manaphy, and Swampert, as they can take on faster threats such as Iron Boulder, Chien-Pao, and Azelf, which all threaten to KO it, while also being able to safely pivot it in. Entry hazard Removal from the likes of Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Mandibuzz is also helpful, as Thundurus-T is very vulnerable to Stealth Rock. Sticky Web support from a teammate like Smeargle or Ribombee is another option, as it can give Thundurus-T the opportunity to outpace previously mentioned revenge killers.

Desolate Land.description: Landorus is a good wallbreaker, taking advantage of Desolate Land's Water-type protection, Weather Ball's type synergy, and its Ground-type STAB moves to blast through Pokemon such as Corviknight, Iron Moth, and Gholdengo. Earth Power is used for its consistency, while Sandsear Storm provides higher power, allowing it to have a chance to OHKO Jirachi and Pixilate Scream Tail after a Nasty Plot; additionally, Sandsear Storm has the ability to burn foes, which can help if it doesn't take the KO. Grass Knot helps Landorus take on bulky Ground-types such as Swampert and Great Tusk, while Stealth Rock lets Landorus support its teammates, weaken its own checks like Primarina and non-Heavy-Duty Boots Dragonite, and threaten common entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight and the aforementioned Great Tusk. Using Leftovers lets Landorus stay on the field longer, while Life Orb lets it OHKO Swampert and 2HKO Primarina with a +2 Grass Knot. Pokemon like Iron Moth, Azelf, and Deoxys-S appreciate Landorus for being able to take on checks like Swampert, Empoleon, and Iron Treads. Landorus struggles to deal with Pokemon that aren't weak to its moves like Manaphy, Blissey, and RegenVest Roaring Moon, so having teammates like Latios, Great Tusk, and Iron Hands will help with taking them down. Similarly, Landorus enjoys having teammates that can remove items with Knock Off such as Roaring Moon, Manaphy, and Azelf, helping it to break down RegenVest Pokemon like Meloetta and Manaphy as well as Pokemon with Heavy-Duty Boots like Dragonite and Mandibuzz. Landorus struggles to switch in on many Pokemon due to its frailty, so it appreciates slow pivots such as Corviknight and Primarina, which also help it by checking offensive Pokemon like Roaring Moon, Iron Boulder, and Walking Wake.

Due to its solid offenses and access to U-turn and Stealth Rock, Landorus-T functions as a mixed attacker, decent pivot, and entry hazard setter. Weather Ball + Desolate Land provides Landorus-T a way to hit physically defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Fluffy Mandibuzz. With U-turn, Landorus-T can switch out of bad matchups against the likes of Dragonite, Well-Baked Body Skarmory, and Primordial Sea Zapdos and bring in Pokemon like Azelf, Iron Hands, and Iron Boulder to check them. Thanks to Desolate Land, Landorus-T is able to successfully wall Empoleon, Barraskewda, and non-Ice Beam Swampert, as well as prevent them from pivoting. Landorus-T helps strong physical attackers such as Roaring Moon and Zamazenta, since they have some trouble breaking through physically defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Fluffy Mandibuzz. Landorus-T also helps special attackers such as Gengar and Latios that have difficulty breaking through specially defensive Pokemon like Hisuian Goodra and Empoleon, which also don't like the hazard chip damage it provides. However, Landorus-T struggles against Dragonite and Well-Baked Body Pokemon such as Skarmory and Chesnaught; Corviknight and Deoxys-D can be used to check Dragonite, while Zapdos and Primarina are options for beating Skarmory and Chesnaught. Landorus-T also tends to struggle against mixed walls such as Manaphy and Ting-Lu; therefore, Iron Hands and Hisuian Electrode make for good partners.

RegenVest.description: RegenVest Meloetta is a capable pivot thanks to its ability to switch into most special attackers like Gholdengo, Scream Tail, Deoxys-S, and Iron Moth. Knock Off gives Meloetta an option to support its teammates by removing key items such as Assault Vest from Swampert and Hisuian Goodra, while Thunderbolt hits Manaphy and non-Volt Absorb Corviknight for high damage. Low Kick lets Meloetta chip Hisuian Goodra and Heatran, but Energy Ball can be used instead to 2HKO Swampert after its Assault Vest has been removed. Good teammates include Pokemon like Roaring Moon, Galarian Zapdos, Barraskewda, and Chien-Pao because Meloetta can safely get them into the field with a slow U-turn. Physical attackers like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao naturally threaten Meloetta out, so Pokemon that can deal with them, like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and defensive Quaquaval, make for good partners. Lastly, Meloetta appreciates entry hazard removal from the likes of Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Mandibuzz, to keep its HP high enough to switch into strong attackers.

Flame Body.description: Chesnaught's bulk, recovery, and useful resistances let it frustrate several common physical attackers, most notably Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-C, and Barraskewda, and Spikes provides utility in nearly every matchup. Flame Body has a 30% chance to end the usefulness of opposing offensive pivots, again, most notably Roaring Moon, and greatly frustrates Rapid Spin Great Tusk attempting to clear Spikes. Iron Defense is the preferred fourth move to set up alongside Bulk Up Great Tusk and Swords Dance users like Iron Hands and Garchomp, while Knock Off can help remove Heavy-Duty Boots to further accentuate Spikes. The given EV spread lets Chesnaught outpace Corviknight, giving it extra chances to fish for a burn, as Brave Bird will not 2HKO it after Iron Defense. Chesnaught mostly finds its home on stall teams, where it can find plenty of teammates to switch into its common weaknesses, especially Fire and Psychic, and can find multiple switch-in opportunities to try and activate Flame Body, which is one of the few ways for stall teams to punish pivoting. Chesnaught is especially horrified of Fire-types like Ceruledge and Cinderace, as they can obliterate it without fear of a burn, and it cannot touch Ghost-types like Gengar and Hisuian Zoroark without Knock Off, so teammates like Well-Baked Body Mandibuzz are strongly recommended.

Magic Guard.description: Despite its low Attack stat, Talonflame carves out a niche as a usable wallbreaker and potent stallbreaker. Roost keeps Talonflame healthy throughout the course of a game, allowing it to reliably act as an offensive check to threats like Ogerpon-H, Great Tusk, and Iron Moth. Bulk Up gives revenge killers like Dragonite and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon a harder time at attempting to revenge kill Talonflame while threatening to let it snowball out of control. Flare Blitz smacks Steel-types like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Iron Treads, while Swords Dance provides greater damage potential, allowing Talonflame to threaten a 2HKO on Pecharunt and OHKO Dragonite from full HP. Taunt allows Talonflame to reliably act as a stallbreaker, preventing would-be checks like Well-Baked Body Corviknight, Unaware Scream Tail, and Deoxys-D from checking it, while Will-O-Wisp provides more utility, burning switch-ins like Garganacl, Primordial Sea Zapdos, and Archaludon. Talonflame requires support from Pokemon that can wear the opposing team down, so entry hazard setters like Great Tusk, Skarmory, and Empoleon are wonderful teammates for it. Talonflame's unimpressive bulk necessitates good teammates that can switch into revenge killers like Azelf, Barraskewda, and Hisuian Electrode; hence, the aforementioned hazard setters, Iron Moth, and Blissey all work as excellent partners for it. Talonflame also notably requires teammates such as RegenVest Swampert and Meloetta that can deal with Fire-immune Electric- and Steel-types like Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, Primordial Sea Zapdos, and Archaludon.

Primordial Sea.description: Primordial Sea Volcanion excels as a fantastic wallbreaker with its great Special Attack and offensive typing. Rain-boosted Steam Eruption combined with Choice Specs allows Volcanion to 2HKO most Pokemon in tier, including most specially defensive walls such as RegenVest Garchomp, Meloetta, and Alolan Muk. Weather Ball dissuades promient Desolate Land users that might want to switch in to Volcanion such as Cinderace and Iron Moth. Earth Power is a more reliable way to deal with Desolate Land users like Iron Moth and Heatran, and it's a reliable way to hit Hisuian Goodra without missing. Focus Blast 2HKOes a would-be check in RegenVest Roaring Moon, as well as Hisuian Goodra after Spikes chip. Volcanion pairs well with entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Garchomp, which help wear down common RegenVest Pokemon like Goodra and Hisuian Goodra, and hazards also guarantee a 2HKO on Meloetta. Due to Volcanion's Stealth Rock weakness it pairs well with hazard removers like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also help pivot it in safely. Volcanion also pairs well with offensive pivots like Zapdos and Roaring Moon, which can help bring it in on targets like Corviknight.

Sheer Force.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack stat improved further by Sheer Force + Life Orb, solid coverage options, and access to Calm Mind, Primarina acts as a threatening wallbreaker and possible bulky sweeper. Energy Ball allows Primarina to nail Swampert and Manaphy. Psychic OHKOes Pecharunt and Desolate Land Iron Moth, while Calm Mind allows Primarina to OHKO Kingambit and RegenVest Iron Hands at +1. Teammates such as Gholdengo and Azelf appreciate Primarina's ability to handle both Swampert and Manaphy, as they tend to be troublesome for them. Primarina is also appreciated for being able to soft check Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao a couple times, which can relieve some pressure off of Great Tusk and Manaphy. Primarina's Water / Fairy typing allows it to hit almost all Pokemon neutrally while also being able to hit special walls like Roaring Moon, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads super effectively. Primarina tends to struggle against many Steel-type Pokemon, precisely Heatran, Empoleon, and Hisuian Goodra, so teammates that can deal with them like Great Tusk and Roaring Moon tend to be good partners. Primarina also struggles to safely switch in on many physical attackers, so slow, physically defensive pivots like Corviknight and Mandibuzz are good teammates. Entry hazard chip quickly wears down Primarina, so hazard removal options such as Great Tusk and the aforementioned Corviknight and Mandibuzz are quite valuable.

Physical Wall.description: Toxapex leverages its high defensive stats and plethora of useful utility moves to act as a stout defensive wall and disruptor. Prankster + Haze lets Toxapex shut down threatening setup sweepers such as Ogerpon-Wellspring, Manaphy, and Stored Power Iron Crown. Corrosion + Toxic gives Toxapex the ability to punish Steel-types such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Desolate Land Heatran, which can otherwise shrug off Toxapex's attacks, while Toxic Spikes can pressure more offensively oriented teams lacking their own Poison-type. Chilling Water deters physical attackers such as Iron Hands and Great Tusk from switching into Toxapex, while Infestation can rack up chip damage on bulkier foes such as Corviknight and Empoleon. Black Sludge give Toxapex greater longevity, while Rocky Helmet punishes physical attackers such as Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, as well as general U-turn spam. Toxapex fits best on stall teams due to its passivity and ability to check setup sweepers that could potentially run rampant. Certain wallbreakers such as Iron Boulder, Garchomp, and Iron Hands are able to power through Toxapex, so teammates that can check these such as Great Tusk and Corviknight are greatly appreciated; Toxapex can in return take on Chien-Pao and Fire-types such as Cinderace and Ogerpon-H. Toxapex is shocked by Electric- and Psychic-types such as Zapdos, Deoxys-S, and Azelf, so teammates that can reliably take these on such as Hisuian Goodra, Mandibuzz, and Meloetta are helpful.

Galvanize.description: Kommo-o finds a decent niche on offensive teams as a mixed attacker with strong coverage. Boomburst scares off walls such as Mandibuzz, Corviknight, and Manaphy. Clanging Scales threatens Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Pecharunt, while Close Combat notably allows Kommo-o to smack special walls like Blissey, Swampert, and Volt Absorb Empoleon attempting to check it. Stealth Rock synergizes well with Kommo-o's ability to scare away entry hazard removers like the aforementioned Mandibuzz and Corviknight. Clangorous Soul allows it to act as a passable setup sweeper instead, preventing threats like Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder from revenge killing it while increasing its offensive capabilities. Life Orb is typically preferred for its consistent damage boost, but Throat Spray can be used on Clangorous Soul sets to avoid recoil. Kommo-o's lack of longevity necessitates either teammates that can make up for its absent defensive utility like Corviknight and Manaphy or offensive teammates that can keep up the pressure like Iron Moth and Chien-Pao. Select revenge killers like Dragonite, Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, and Azelf naturally outspeed Kommo-o even after a Clangorous Soul, so answers to them like Kingambit, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon make for good partners. Kommo-o appreciates pivots like Azelf, Sandy Shocks, and Roaring Moon because they can pivot out on their checks like Blissey, Empoleon, and Corviknight and safely bring it in to start threatening the opposing team. Kommo-o greatly appreciates dual screens support from setters like Corviknight and Deoxys-S allowing it to have an easier time setting up with Clangorous Soul or supporting its teammates with Stealth Rock; alternatively, Sticky Web from Smeargle and Ribombee can help it outspeed Choice Scarf revenge killers like Latios, Azelf, and Roaring Moon after a Clangorous Soul.

Magic Guard.description: Cinderace's high Speed, high Attack, and wide utility movepool make it a versatile attacker that can both dish out substantial damage and disrupt opposing Pokemon indirectly. High Jump Kick hits Garganacl while also being the best option against Well-Baked Body users such as Corviknight and Skarmory, and Gunk Shot hits Scream Tail, Primarina, and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Cinderace can use Will-O-Wisp to cripple would-be switch-ins such as Great Tusk, Garchomp, Swampert, and Dragonite, pivot out on them with U-turn, or carry Gunk Shot for maximum coverage. Swords Dance helps Cinderace wallbreak, while Taunt prevents foes from inflicting status, recovering, or controlling entry hazards, which Cinderace can control itself with Court Change. In particular, Taunt improves Cinderace's matchup against Unaware users such as Mandibuzz and Scream Tail by prohibiting their recovery. Life Orb amplifies Cinderace's damage output, while Focus Sash provides recourse against Pokemon that would otherwise OHKO it, allowing it to score surprise KOs or get off valuable utility moves in a pinch. Magic Guard removes Life Orb recoil, the chance for Focus Sash to be broken by indirect damage, and Cinderace's vulnerability to Entry Hazard damage. Cinderace's ability to pressure Corviknight and Skarmory is appreciated by other wallbreakers that can struggle to deal with them like Roaring Moon, Iron Boulder, and Barraskewda, all of which Cinderace can help enter the field with U-turn. Cinderace is threatened by faster Pokemon like Zamazenta and Deoxys-S, so defensive Pokemon that can switch into these such as Empoleon, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz are helpful partners. Well-Baked Body Gholdengo completely walls Cinderace, making partners that can force out or eliminate it like Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Gengar valuable teammates.

Primordial Sea.description: Inteleon is a decent cleaner and wallbreaker thanks to its high Special Attack and Speed, threatening many offensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Scream Tail, and Gholdengo. U-turn lets it pivot out of unfavorable matchups like RegenVest Manaphy and Primarina and forms a VoltTurn core with other pivots like Roaring Moon and Meowscarada. Mud Shot threatens Fire-types like Iron Moth and Cinderace that could otherwise utilize Desolate Land to comfortably switch into a Weather Ball and OHKOes Heatran. Ice Beam snipes Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Latios. Physical teammates like Zamazenta and Roaring Moon appreciate Inteleon's ability to threaten their switch-ins like Pecharunt and Great Tusk, respectively, letting them rip massive holes in the opponent's team once these foes are removed; in return, they can threaten walls like Empoleon and Manaphy, which Inteleon struggles against. Entry hazard support from the likes of Scream Tail and Ting-Lu helps Inteleon against special walls like Empoleon and RegenVest users like Manaphy and Primarina, which it otherwise struggles to break through. Inteleon is also vulnerable to being worn down by hazards, so teammates that can remove them like Corviknight and Great Tusk are good partners. Furthermore, Inteleon's frailty leaves it severely threatened by faster revenge killers like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, making teammates that can deal with them like the aforementioned Corviknight and Great Tusk greatly appreciated.

Dual Screens.description:
With its remarkable defensive profile and utility options, Prankster Corviknight becomes an effective lead at setting dual screens to support its teammates. Prankster-boosted Taunt allows Corviknight to shut down foes like Great Tusk, Skarmory, and Regieleki from setting their entry hazards or own dual screens; stop Cinderace and opposing Corviknight from removing its dual screens with Court Change and Defog; prevent offensive threats like Zamazenta, all Ogerpon formes, and Iron Boulder from using it as setup fodder; block Trick from Choice item users like Scream Tail and Gholdengo from crippling it; and additionally stop defensive Pokemon like Gholdengo, Scream Tail, and non-Prankster Pecharunt from healing freely, letting its teammates overwhelm them more easily. U-turn makes use of Corviknight's middling Speed tier to support its teammates by bringing them in safely after stomaching an attack, and it's especially valuable against Dark-type foes like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Taunt Roaring Moon that can otherwise set up in front of or even shut down Corviknight.

Corviknight is exclusively found on dual screens hyper offense teams.
