As a result, high caliber offensive threats like Tail Glow Manaphy, IronPress Zamazenta, and Dragon Dance Roaring Moon pair well with it, as they appreciate Corviknight bringing them in safely through U-turn and its dual screens to set up more easily. However, Double Dance sweepers such as Iron Crown and Galarian Moltres benefit from said dual screens even more, as they require multiple turns of setup before wreaking havoc. Other setup sweepers like Iron Boulder, Iron Hands, and Kingambit have the added benefit of threatening Cinderace and Defoggers like opposing Corviknight and Mandibuzz—especially since Mandibuzz can use Defog freely even in the face of Corviknight—preventing them any free opportunities of ever removing Corviknight's dual screens. Since other foes like Zapdos, Iron Moth, and Dark-types like Roaring Moon and Kingambit can also use Corviknight as entry points, teammates that can come in afterwards to either threaten or use them as setup fodder are also beneficial, with the aforementioned Iron Boulder, Deoxys-S, Zamazenta, and Great Tusk capable of doing so. Furthermore, Corviknight's ability to prevent Stealth Rock from going up with Taunt also gives setup sweepers like Ogerpon-Hearthflame and Chien-Pao more opportunities to get rolling.

Immunity.description:
Corviknight's great utility and defensive typing, further bolstered by an immunity-granting ability, make it an excellent special wall and defensive pivot. Volt Absorb lets it counter Electric-types such as Zapdos and Sandy Shocks and helps against special attackers that rely on Electric-type coverage, such as Deoxys-S, Latios, and Iron Crown. Similarly, Well-Baked Body shuts down Ogerpon-H, Moltres, and non-Discharge Iron Moth. Brave Bird is the go-to STAB move, while Body Press is an option on Well-Baked Body sets to take advantage of the Defense boosts. U-turn generates momentum for Corviknight’s teammates, and Defog provides valuable hazard control. A Sassy nature with 0 Speed IVs is crucial for Corviknight's role as a slow pivot.

Corviknight fits on balance and bulky offense teams, where its longevity and consistency gives it a niche over Iron Treads. Corviknight can pivot in more offensive teammates like Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-H, which also appreciate its ability to remove entry hazards. Corviknight is threatened by physical wallbreakers such as Zamazenta and Ogerpon-W, making physically defensive walls like Great Tusk and Pecharunt good teammates. Corviknight can also be overwhelmed by neutral special attacks from Gholdengo and Primarina, so it needs backup from RegenVest users like Manaphy and Swampert. In exchange, Volt Absorb Corviknight helps Manaphy answer Electric-types, while Well-Baked Body helps Swampert answer Fire-types carrying Grass-type coverage like Iron Moth and Heatran.

Choice Band.description: With great offensive stats and a spammable move in Flip Turn, Barraskewda serves as an excellent offensive pivot that's capable of outpacing the majority of the metagame. Close Combat lets it deal with foes that resist its Water-type moves such as Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-W, and Empoleon, while Aqua Jet lets it pick off weakened foes that normally outspeed it such as Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Hisuian Electrode, as well as foes that have set up, such as Volcarona and Great Tusk. Drill Run and Psychic Fangs also threaten Water-resistant foes, with Drill Run OHKOing Desolate Land Fire-types such as Iron Moth, Heatran, and Ceruledge and Psychic Fangs threatening Quaquaval and Kommo-o. Barraskewda takes great advantage of weakened walls such as Corviknight and Deoxys-D, making physical wallbreakers such as Iron Boulder, Galarian Zapdos, and Ceruledge good partners. Specially offensive pivots such as Hisuian Electrode and Azelf form great VoltTurn cores with Barraskewda, since they're able to threaten each other's checks, with Barraskewda forcing out special walls such as Meloetta and Swampert while they threaten physical walls such as Corviknight and Quaquaval in return. Barraskewda is very frail and easily OHKOed by faster foes such as Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Azelf, which makes defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Swampert necessary. It also struggles a lot with entry hazards, making hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Corviknight appreciated.

IronPress.description:
IronPress Zamazenta serves as a deadly wincon that provides great defensive utility, leveraging its excellent bulk and useful Dark resistance to switch into dangerous threats like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon and use these opportunities to set up or wallbreak. Stone Edge threatens Flying-types like Zapdos and Moltres and is Zamazenta's strongest move against Fluffy Landorus-T, while Crunch hits Ghost-types like Pecharunt, Gholdengo, and Sinistcha. The given Attack EVs allow Stone Edge to OHKO Moltres without Expert Belt. With Expert Belt, Crunch 2HKOes physically defensive Gholdengo after minimal chip damage and has near-guaranteed odds of 3HKOing non-Intimidate Pecharunt; this item also allows Stone Edge to OHKO offensive Zapdos. The remaining EVs are invested into Defense to power up Body Press and let Zamazenta answer physical threats better.

IronPress Zamazenta best fits on both balance and offensive teams that appreciate its defensive utility and potency as a wincon. Offensive Pokemon such as Roaring Moon, Zapdos, and Gholdengo that can lure in setup fodder like Great Tusk, Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Swampert for Zamazenta pair well with it. Bulky Fighting-resistant foes unafraid of Zamazenta's coverage like Pecharunt, Primarina, and defensive Landorus-I are its biggest roadblocks; thus, teammates that can deal with them such as Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Latios pair well with it. Kingambit is an especially notable partner, as it complements Zamazenta both offensively and defensively extremely well, with Kingambit switching into and threatening the Ghost- and Psychic-types Zamazenta detests, while Zamazenta deals with Kingambit's checks like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Body Press Corviknight. Zamazenta is forced out by threats that can either outspeed and threaten it or survive a hit and attack in return like Latios, Deoxys-S, and Scream Tail; thus, teammates that can deal with them like Iron Treads, Swampert, and Manaphy are greatly appreciated.

Zamazenta-C leverages its Fighting / Steel typing and high Defense and Speed to be a decent Body Press sweeper that's able to switch in and set up on common Pokemon like Corviknight, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon. Stone Edge helps against Zapdos, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge, while Substitute helps it set up against would-be switch-ins like Iron Hands and Great Tusk as well as shielding it from status afflictions from moves like Manaphy's Scald and Corrosion Pecharun't Toxic. Zamazenta-C plays best on offensive teams, so it appreciates entry hazards from Pokemon like Skarmory and Deoxys-D and dual screens support from Pokemon like Corviknight and Deoxys-S, which help it take KOs and set up, respectively. Zamazenta-C also appreciates Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Gengar that are able to take down Deoxys-D, Gholdengo, and Pecharunt, as otherwise it is unable to make progress at all.

Dual Screens.description: With the highest base Speed in the game, Regieleki can enable high-powered setup sweepers like Manaphy, Kingambit, and Iron Hands on hyper offense teams as a dual screens lead, though it's more niche than other dual screens setters. With Refrigerate, Rapid Spin is a guaranteed way to remove entry hazards even in the face of Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Pecharunt. However, Regieleki isn't the best to rely on for Rapid Spin all of the time, so teammates like Great Tusk and Quaquaval can help as additional spinners. Explosion lets Regieleki get its teammates in safely, do massive damage to foes like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon, and prevent dual screens removal via Defog. Many setup sweepers, most notably Gholdengo and Iron Hands, appreciate Regieleki's dual screens support while also fending off priority from Pokemon like Slither Wing and Prankster Corviknight, which would otherwise prevent it from setting dual screens. Regieleki similarly doesn't enjoy Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Meowscarada, as they are the only relevant Pokemon able to outspeed it instantly, so having checks to them such as Kingambit, Iron Hands, and Zamazenta can help. As a final note, Regieleki is exclusively a hyper offense lead meant to support Pokemon such as Iron Boulder, Gengar, and Kingambit by providing them with extra opportunities to set up and win the game.

Calm Mind.description: Ursaluna-B uses its great Special Attack and physical bulk to be a decent Calm Mind sweeper. Calm Mind lets it boost past and break through foes like Corviknight and RegenVest Manaphy and Swampert, while Moonlight provides additional longevity, letting it use the aforementioned walls as setup fodder. Storm Drain turns RegenVest users like Swampert, Manaphy, and Primarina into setup fodder and lets it check Barraskewda; alternatively, Well-Baked Body lets Ursaluna-B counter Fire-types like Ceruledge lacking Close Combat, Iron Moth, and Heatran, letting it safely set up on them, while Fluffy lets it deal with physical attackers, using Dragonite as setup fodder and checking Fighting-types like Iron Hands and Great Tusk. 252 Special Attack EVs and a Modest nature lets Ursaluna-B OHKO Dragonite at +1 and defensive Great Tusk, while 252 Defense EVs and a Bold nature help Ursaluna-B better check physical attackers like Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder. 15 Speed IVs let Ursaluna-B underspeed Corviknight, preventing it from safely using Roost or U-turn to slow pivot to a teammate that can handle Ursaluna-B. Powerful special attackers like Azelf and Latios appreciate Ursaluna-B's ability to handle threats like Roaring Moon and pressure checks like Swampert for them; in return, they can threaten Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Great Tusk that could threaten it. Ursaluna-B's low Speed leaves it susceptible to threats that can OHKO it like Chien-Pao and Latios, so teammates that can deal with them like RegenVest Primarina are appreciated. Ursaluna-B's low Special Defense also lets powerful attackers like Latios and Deoxys-S OHKO it prior to setting up, so specially defensive teammates that can check them like Empoleon and Heatran are good pairings. Earth Eater users like Gholdengo and Empoleon can wall Ursaluna-B, so teammates that can threaten them like Roaring Moon and Scrappy Great Tusk are appreciated.

Choice Item.description: Thanks to its high base Attack and Speed stats and U-turn, Meowscarada functions incredibly as an offensive pivot and wallbreaker. U-turn allows Meowscarada to switch out of problematic matchups such as Corviknight and Kingambit and into threats like Iron Moth and Iron Hands to scare them away. Trick enables Meowscarada to punish bulky walls like Corviknight, Skarmory, and Mandibuzz looking to switch in on it; alternatively, Triple Axel provides a way for Meowscarada to hit Dragonite, Mandibuzz, and Chesnaught for super effective damage. Meowscarada can use Choice Band to OHKO Deoxys-D, Scream Tail, and Garganacl after Stealth Rock, while Choice Scarf gives it the ability to outspeed incredibly fast foes such as Deoxys-S, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Roaring Moon. Since Meowscarada struggles against Corviknight, Skarmory, and Kingambit, it appreciates partners like Zapdos, Sandy Shocks, and Archaludon that can pressure them; in return, Meowscarada can threaten Swampert and Meloetta, which these teammates struggle against. While Meowscarada's Attack stat is adequate, it still appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Deoxys-D, Garchomp, and Heatran, as Stealth Rock or one layer of Spikes allows Meowscarada to have a very high chance of OHKOing Deoxys-D and Scream Tail.

The Salt Cure.description: Garganacl is a tough defensive wall that uses Salt Cure to wear down defensive Pokemon, like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Corviknight, and utilizes its ability selection to check a variety of different Pokemon. Fluffy allows Garganacl to check Kingambit and Iron Boulder, Water Absorb lets it reliably switch in on defensive Manaphy as well as help with checking Choice-locked Water-types like Barraskewda and Primarina, and Earth Eater lets it check Roaring Moon and Dragonite running Earthquake. Stealth Rock lets Garganacl support its teammates by providing entry hazards, while with Iron Defense or Curse, Garganacl can set up on and more easily check Pokemon like Iron Hands, Ceruledge, and Dragonite, and boost Body Press or Earthquake, depending on the set. When using Body Press, Garganacl can more efficiently take on Chien-Pao as well as a majority of other Pokemon, while with Earthquake, it can deal with Iron Boulder and Pecharunt. Protect lets Garganacl deal extra damage with Salt Cure active as well as gain some extra Leftovers recovery. Garganacl can either use Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots, the former letting it gain more recovery through Protect and the latter helping Garganacl switch in more often. Garganacl provides great defensive support to frail offensive Pokemon, like Iron Moth, Gengar, and Galarian Zapdos, as a to check faster Pokemon like Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Iron Boulder. Garganacl can struggle against special attackers, such as Deoxys-S, Azelf, and offensive Gholdengo, so having specially defensive teammates, like Hisuian Goodra, Manaphy, and Blissey, can help. Garganacl enjoys being on more defensive teams for having teammates that can take on physical attackers with it, such as Pecharunt, Mandibuzz, and Primarina, as it struggles to reliably check Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Zamazenta, and Barraskewda.

Bulk Up.description: Palafin is an extremely niche setup sweeper that has one of the strongest priority moves in the tier and not much else, as it is forced to use Zero to Hero to transform. Substitute prevents it from being statused from Pecharunt, Gholdengo, and Manaphy while allowing it to set up on passive targets like Corviknight, Swampert, and the aforementioned Manaphy. Bulk Up makes up for its lack of power, since it lacks an ability and item that increases its damage output. Drain Punch keeps Palafin healthy against checks like Corviknight and Manaphy and allows it to damage Water-immune foes like Iron Moth and Heatran. Ice Punch smacks Dragon-types like Dragonite and Roaring Moon, while Zen Headbutt OHKOes Iron Moth. Palafin fits on bulkier or balance teams as a late-game sweeper, so partners that can wear the opposing team down over time like Magic Guard Roaring Moon, Hisuian Electrode, and Deoxys-S are appreciated; entry hazard setters like Scream Tail, Heatran, and Great Tusk are also beneficial with their ability to chip down foes over time. Palafin is checked offensively by threats like Dragonite, Desolate Land Ceruledge, and Scream Tail, so teammates like Corviknight, Well-Baked Body Mandibuzz, and Heatran handle these threats. Physical walls like Pecharunt and Skarmory can wall Palafin consistently, so partners that can force them out like Deoxys-S and Sandy Shocks pair well with it. Desolate Land users like Iron Moth Roaring Moon, Primordial Sea Zapdos, and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo can deal with Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Heatran, making for great partners.

Great Tusk.comments:
Other Options

Wandering Spirit is a niche ability on physically defensive sets that prevents Regenerator Pokemon like Swampert and Roaring Moon from regaining their HP when they pivot out while also letting Great Tusk gain Regenerator. Magic Guard + Life Orb is a great combination for offensive sets, as this prevents Great Tusk from being chipped down by Rocky Helmet and poison from Malignant Chain or Toxic Spikes; it also lets Great Tusk make use of Supercell Slam to hit Corviknight and Skarmory as well as Head Smash for Zapdos and Moltres without taking any recoil. Mold Breaker is used on offensive sets to allow Great Tusk to bypass Fluffy used on Pokemon like Corviknight, Skarmory, and Great Tusk as well as Levitate and Earth Eater on Gholdengo and Pecharunt. Earth Eater gives Great Tusk immunity to Earthquake from Ting-Lu, Swampert, and opposing Great Tusk while also letting it counter Sandy Shocks. Great Tusk can opt for an EV spread of 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Spe to make it a fast utility Pokemon while still retaining its defensive prowess. Eject Button is a niche item that swings the momentum in your favor against Pokemon trying to pivot out with U-turn such as Roaring Moon and Corviknight.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Great Tusk's incredibly low Special Defense makes it prone to being OHKOed by special attackers like Deoxys-S, Zapdos, Scream Tail, Gholdengo, and Iron Moth.

Physical Attackers With Super Effective Moves: Chien-Pao, Iron Boulder, Meowscarada, and the Ogerpon formes can all 2HKO Great Tusk with their super effective attacks.

Residual Damage: Residual damage like poison, Spikes, and Rocky Helmet all slowly chip away at Great Tusk, which is compounded by it lacking any sort of longevity if it isn't using Regenerator or Leftovers.

Physically Defensive.description:
Thanks to its enormous physical bulk, solid utility options, and wide variety of abilities it can use, Great Tusk functions as an excellent physical wall. Earthquake lets Great Tusk hit foes that would otherwise beat it like Pecharunt, Scream Tail, and defensive Gholdengo, whereas Body Press does more damage than Earthquake due to its defensive investment and does solid damage to non-Fluffy Corviknight and Skarmory. Knock Off allows Great Tusk to annoy switch-ins like Corviknight, Skarmory, and opposing Great Tusk by removing their items, while Ice Spinner does good damage to Zapdos. Rapid Spin allows Great Tusk to support its teammates by removing entry hazards. Stealth Rock lets Great Tusk residually chip Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Deoxys-S, and Heatran, while Taunt prevents Corviknight from using Defog, Skarmory from setting up hazards, and both of them from recovering with Roost. Scrappy lets Great Tusk use Rapid Spin against Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Pecharunt while also being able to hit Gholdengo with Body Press; however, Regenerator gives Great Tusk longevity, which lets it check Roaring Moon and opposing Great Tusk without being scared of getting chipped down, but this means that Great Tusk is forced to be used with non-RegenVest special walls. Alternatively, Fluffy makes Great Tusk incredibly bulky, letting it easily switch in on Choice Band Zamazenta and Roaring Moon. Leftovers is appreciated on Scrappy and Fluffy sets, as Great Tusk lacks longevity, but Rocky Helmet is also an option to punish Corviknight, opposing Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and non-Magic Guard Roaring Moon. Heavy-Duty Boots is a bit more niche, but it lets Great Tusk remove hazards without being affected by them.

Defensive Great Tusk is most often used on bulky offense or balance teams. Attackers that are easily chipped down by entry hazards like Chien-Pao, Deoxys-S, and non-Magic Guard Roaring Moon appreciate Great Tusk removing them with Rapid Spin. Teammates like Zapdos, Roaring Moon, and Iron Moth enjoy the Stealth Rock that Great Tusk sets up, as they can pivot out to slowly chip away at switch-ins such as Corviknight and RegenVest Roaring Moon. Great Tusk's low Special Defense requires special walls like RegenVest Manaphy, Swampert, and Roaring Moon as well as Heatran, Iron Treads, and Empoleon for Regenerator variants of Great Tusk. Great Tusk is also vulnerable to physical attackers like Chien-Pao, Iron Boulder, Meowscarada, and the Ogerpon formes; therefore, it appreciates aid from Pokemon such as physically defensive Manaphy, Skarmory, and Moltres.

Choice Band.description:
Great Tusk's powerful STAB moves, massive attack stat, and Choice Band make it one of the strongest wallbreakers in the tier. Knock Off cripples Moltres and Zapdos by removing their Heavy-Duty Boots while helping to make progress against Corviknight and opposing Great Tusk by removing Rocky Helmet or Leftovers. It is also required on Sword of Ruin sets to hit Earth Eater Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Pecharunt. Ice Spinner handles Flying-types like Zapdos and the Landorus formes that Great Tusk would otherwise struggle with, and Rapid Spin provides useful entry hazard control. Mold Breaker lets Great Tusk completely ignore Earth Eater on the aforementioned Gholdengo and Pecharunt, as well as bypassing Fluffy on Corviknight, Skarmory, and opposing Great Tusk. Sword of Ruin trades these matchups for more power, notably letting Great Tusk potentially 2HKO Corviknight through Intimidate.

Choice Band Great Tusk works best on offense and balance teams, where other physical attackers can make up for its subpar Speed and take advantage of weakened physically defensive walls. Great Tusk can tailor its ability to the team's need, such as running Sword of Ruin when paired with Chien-Pao, thus being able to break past Corviknight regardless of whether it has Intimidate or Fluffy. Similarly, Choice Band Zamazenta can handle Intimidate Corviknight, while Mold Breaker Great Tusk helps threaten both Fluffy Corviknight and Pecharunt. Due to its low Speed and Special Defense, Great Tusk is vulnerable to special attackers such as Latios, Deoxys, and Scream Tail; special walls like Manaphy, Iron Treads, and Swampert can check these threats while also pivoting Great Tusk in.

Offensive Bulk Up.description: Impressive offensive and defensive utility combined with the ability to remove entry hazards cements Great Tusk as a threatening sweeper that also takes on threats like Ceruledge, Iron Hands, and Roaring Moon. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk hit Flying-types like Dragonite, Zapdos, and Mandibuzz, while Knock Off instead debilitates defensive switch-ins like Mandibuzz, Fluffy Corviknight, and opposing Great Tusk. Headlong Rush helps deal with Poison-types like Pecharunt and Iron Moth as well as being Great Tusk's best option against Fairy-types like Scream Tail. Scrappy + Rapid Spin grants Great Tusk hazard removal that's not blocked by Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Pecharunt. Scrappy also notably enables Great Tusk to turn Intimidate Corviknight into setup fodder. Hazard-weak Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, Ceruledge, and Ogerpon-H appreciate Great Tusk's role as a spinner; in return, they can help threaten physically defensive checks like Fluffy Corviknight and Deoxys-D, making it easier for it to set up. Due to its mediocre Special Defense, Great Tusk is forced out by common threats such as Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Latios, making specially defensive teammates such as RegenVest Swampert, Meloetta, and Manaphy necessary. Despite its fantastic natural physical bulk, Great Tusk is troubled by certain wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao, Galarian Zapdos, and all Ogerpon formes, making physically defensive teammates such as Intimidate Skarmory, Fluffy Corviknight, and Unaware Deoxys-D greatly appreciated.

Scream Tail.comments:
Other Options

Calm Mind lets Scream Tail become a threatening setup sweeper, letting it 2HKO RegenVest Swampert and Manaphy at +2 while also allowing it to potentially outlast switch-ins like Iron Moth and Moltres. Unaware + Calm Mind is a solid strategy on hyper offense teams to let Scream Tail set up and obliterate the foe with Stored Power and destroy Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao with Dazzling Gleam. Fire Blast or Flamethrower allow Scream Tail to break through Steel-types like Corviknight and Iron Treads that it usually struggles against. Choice Specs lets Scream Tail 3HKO RegenVest Manaphy and Swampert while 2HKOing them without their Assault Vest, but Scream Tail usually prefers not to use a Choice item due to its wide variety of utility moves.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Steel-types like Iron Treads, Heatran, and Gholdengo resist both Boomburst and Psychic Noise and can threaten Scream Tail with their STAB moves.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: RegenVest Swampert and Manaphy can switch into Scream Tail with ease and easily pivot out to an offensive threat.

Fast Offensive Threats: Without a Choice Scarf, Scream Tail gets outsped and OHKOed by Zamazenta, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Choice Band Roaring Moon.

Pixilate.description:
Thanks to its fantastic utility movepool, solid defensive stats and typing, and access to Boomburst + Pixilate, Scream Tail functions as a strong attacker, Stealth Rock setter, and decent defensive switch-in to threats like Iron Hands, Latios, and Deoxys-S. Boomburst + Pixilate enables Scream Tail to deal considerable damage, 2HKOing common threats like Zapdos, Kingambit, and RegenVest Iron Hands while bypassing Substitute from Zamazenta and OHKOing it. Psychic Noise hits Iron Moth and Pecharunt on top of preventing switch-ins like Corviknight and Gholdengo from healing; however, Stealth Rock is also an option. Wish grants Scream Tail longevity as well as letting it heal partners low on HP. Protect lets it guarantee healing from Wish, heal more from Leftovers, and scout the move that dangerous Choice item attackers like Gholdengo, Roaring Moon, and Zamazenta are using. Trick should be used exclusively on Choice Scarf sets to punish switch-ins like RegenVest Swampert and Manaphy as well as Iron Treads and Corviknight, benefiting other special wallbreakers like Gholdengo and Latios. Leftovers provides Scream Tail with extra longevity, Heavy-Duty Boots prevents chip damage from entry hazards, and Choice Scarf gives it valuable speed control, letting it outspeed non-Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Deoxys-S.

Scream Tail is best suited for bulky offense and balance teams that make use of its offensive and defensive utility as well as its ability to set Stealth Rock and threaten or sit on most entry hazard removers with ease. Teammates that lack longevity like non-Regenerator Great Tusk, the Landorus formes, and Iron Treads appreciate Scream Tail for its ability to provide them healing with Wish. Teammates like Gholdengo and Iron moth that struggle with removing RegenVest Iron Hands and Roaring Moon benefit from Scream Tail being able to easily beat them with Boomburst; in return, Gholdengo and Iron Moth can threaten opposing Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Assault Vest Iron Crown. Knock Off users like Roaring Moon, Great Tusk, and Manaphy can help Scream Tail by removing Assault Vest from Swampert and opposing Manaphy, letting it 3HKO them. Scream Tail is threatened by entry hazards if it is not running Heavy-Duty Boots, so it requires an entry hazard remover like Corviknight, Great Tusk, or Iron Treads.

Iron Treads.comments:
Other Options

Earth Power can be used over Earthquake to deal more damage to Great Tusk and Pecharunt, but the higher power of Earthquake is generally more appreciated. An mixed attacking set of Magic Guard + Life Orb with Steel Beam and Earthquake can be used due to its potential to break through Great Tusk and Swampert relatively easily, but this is a very niche set that struggles to break through Corviknight and Manaphy. Immunity abilities can be used to cover for some of the weaknesses Iron Treads has: Earth Eater for Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and the Landorus formes; Water Absorb for Manaphy and Primarina; and Well-Baked Body for Iron Moth and Heatran. Bulletproof sets can run Assault Vest if not running Stealth Rock for the extra bulk against strong special attackers like Zapdos, Deoxys-S, and Latios, but without Leftovers, Iron Treads lacks any form of recovery.

Checks and Counters

Physical Attackers: Physical attackers like Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Chien-Pao easily destroy Iron Treads with their STAB moves.

Ground-types: Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and the Landorus formes block Volt Switch and can demolish Iron Treads with Earthquake.

Strong Special Attackers: Strong special attackers like Choice Specs Latios, Gholdengo, and Deoxys-S can break through Iron Treads's non-RegenVest set with their STAB moves due to Iron Treads's low special bulk and lack of recovery.

Specially Defensive.description:
Iron Treads's amazing defensive typing, access to incredible utility moves, and decent defensive stats let it function as a specially defensive staple for many teams. Rapid Spin lets it support Stealth Rock-weak teammates like Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-H by removing entry hazards. Knock Off punishes switch-ins like Corviknight and Great Tusk by removing their Leftovers or Rocky Helmet, whereas Ice Spinner punishes would-be switch-ins like Garchomp and the Landorus formes. Volt Switch gives Iron Treads the ability to pivot and provide its teammates with momentum, while Stealth Rock offers valuable role compression. Bulletproof grants it immunity to Shadow Ball from Gholdengo, Weather Ball from Moltres and Zapdos, Pyro Ball from Cinderace, and Focus Blast from Deoxys-S, making Iron Treads a great switch-in to those Pokemon. 12 Speed EVs and a Jolly nature let Iron Treads outspeed Zamazenta at +1 and maximum Speed Modest Gholdengo at +0.

Iron Treads is best suited for more offense-based teams due to its subpar special bulk and lack of reliable recovery, which it makes up for with much-needed role compression. Iron Treads excellently complements physically defensive RegenVest Manaphy, as Iron Treads can check Zapdos, Latios, and Gholdengo for Manaphy, while it checks Chien-Pao and Great Tusk for Iron Treads. Physical attackers like Zamazenta, Roaring Moon, and Great Tusk pose a problem for Iron Treads; therefore, physically defensive partners like Pecharunt and Skarmory are appreciated. Primordial Sea partners like Zapdos, Ogerpon-W, and Primarina are helpful to deal with Fire-types like Iron Moth, Heatran, and Ogerpon-H that can destroy Iron Treads with ease.

RegenVest.description: Iron Treads is a niche RegenVest wall that offers valuable Rapid Spin utility, pivoting, and a unique typing that resists the tier's common Psychic- and Electric-type special attacks. Volt Switch provides pivoting while also chipping switch-ins like Corviknight and Manaphy, whereas Knock Off greatly reduces the longevity of defensive walls, notably Great Tusk and Swampert who would normally come in to absorb Volt Switch. Iron Treads is a pain to deal with for fast Electric-types, including Hisuian Electrode and non-Weather Ball Zapdos, and it can survive a Focus Blast from Thundurus or an Earth Power from Sandy Shocks. It also acts as a reliable answer to Azelf, Latios, and Gholdengo, threatening them with Knock Off while not being crippled by Trick. Iron Treads fits best on stall teams, providing much-needed hazard removal while relying on other specially defensive walls like Empoleon and Blissey to cover its weaknesses to common special attackers such as Primarina, Sandy Shocks, and Iron Moth. Iron Treads also appreciates physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Toxapex, as it naturally loses to some of the tier's most common physical wallbreakers such as Ceruledge, Chien-Pao, and Galarian Zapdos. Iron Treads can also be run as a role compression option on more offensive teams, as it can provide semi-reliable pivoting and Rapid Spin support for Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-H; in return, they threaten the Ground-types that Iron Treads struggles against such as the aforementioned Swampert and Great Tusk.

Earth Eater.description: Swords Dance, huge bulk, and a good defensive typing allow Iron Hands to become an incredibly threatening wallbreaker. Earth Eater allows it to set up on would-be checks like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Sandy Shocks. Substitute allows it to take advantage of foes like Empoleon, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao, which are forced out by it, allowing it valuable turns to set up. 172 Special Defense EVs allow its Substitute and withstand a Scald from RegenVest Manaphy, while 196 Speed EVs let it outspeed Manaphy. It is next to impossible to OHKO a full health Iron Hands behind dual screens, so support from Prankster Corviknight and Deoxys-S on hyper offense teams can help by allowing it extra turns to set up and letting it beat would-be offensive checks like Latios and Primarina. Iron Hands struggles against Unaware Pokemon, in particular Deoxys-D and Scream Tail, so teammates that can threaten them like Gengar and Ceruledge make for good partners. Barraskewda and Chien-Pao are teammates that enjoy the presence of Iron Hands, as it is excellent at trading itself to remove would-be checks to them like physically defensive Primarina and Manaphy, Intimidate Corviknight, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon. Strong special attackers like Deoxys-S, Azelf, and Latios can be troublesome for Iron Hands, forcing it out; as a result, bulky special walls like Swampert, Manaphy, and Blissey are appreciated by it.

Surge Surfer.description: Surge Surfer Iron Hands is a great wallbreaker, leveraging the Speed boost procured by its ability to outspeed almost the entire unboosted metagame and set up with Swords Dance in order to break though opposing teams. It also has a great matchup against a lot of defensive staples such as Corviknight and Gholdengo. Ice Punch allows Iron Hands to hit Garchomp and foes that resist its STAB combination such as Latios, Dragonite, and Landorus-T for greater damage. Since Iron Hands is reliant on Electric Terrain to function, it must be paired with a Hadron Engine pivot such as Latios or Sandy Shocks, both of which can apply additional pressure on Great Tusk; in return, Iron Hands can beat Pokemon that Sandy Shocks is unable to hit such as Landorus-T. Iron Hands is not a conventional wallbreaker, and it can struggle to power through teams on its own; therefore, teammates such as Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder are appreciated, as they can apply pressure on Pokemon such as Deoxys-D and physically defensive Great Tusk, respectively, which Iron Hands struggles against. Pivots such as Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos are also great partners, as they can bait in Pokemon that Iron Hands can easily take advantage of to set up, such as Primarina and Corviknight.

RegenVest.description: Iron Hands's great natural bulk and typing let it serve as a potent mixed wall and pivot, checking and scouting common threats like Gholdengo, Iron Moth, Chien-Pao, and Dragonite. Drain Punch provides a drawback-free STAB move with recovery, while Close Combat grants more immediate power, being able to 2HKO Swampert. Earthquake allows Iron Hands to threaten offensive wallbreakers like Gengar, Iron Moth, and Gholdengo, while Ice Punch can help to hit Ground-types like Great Tusk that can block Volt Switch and Flying-types like Zapdos and Dragonite. Iron Hands struggles with strong Psychic- and Fairy-type wallbreakers like Azelf and Primarina, so it appreciates partners like Empoleon and Mandibuzz that can help with these matchups. Iron Hands dislikes common defensive Ground-types like Great Tusk and Swampert that can block its attempt to pivot with Volt Switch, and it can struggle against particularly strong physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, so it partners well with walls that can handle them like Corviknight and Deoxys-D. Frail offensive wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Azelf appreciate Iron Hands's ability to safely pivot them onto the field and wall revenge killers like Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Roaring Moon.

Iron Moth.comments:
Other Options

Iron Moth has a deep movepool it can dig into to suit the needs of its team. Overheat is an incredibly powerful nuke on Desolate Land and Hadron Engine sets at the cost of being more punishable by Fire-resistant foes like Roaring Moon. Toxic is an option over Toxic Spikes on Desolate Land sets to directly threaten enemies with debilitating status, but Toxic Spikes is usually preferred for its ability to status multiple foes. Energy Ball is an option over Solar Beam on Desolate Land sets to hit Primordial Sea Primarina and to not get locked in against Primordial Sea Zapdos, but Solar Beam is generally preferred for its power. Both Iron Moth sets can look into their movepool for options like Psychic for opposing Iron Moth and Pecharunt or, on Desolate Land sets, Dazzling Gleam to hit Roaring Moon on the switch in, but these moves are either too risky to use or don't provide enough value compared to the suggested moves. Iron Moth can consider dropping a coverage move for Toxic to threaten checks like Swampert and Blissey, but this is usually less useful than a third attacking move.

Checks and Counters

Primordial Sea Users: Primordial Sea users like Ogerpon-W, Archaludon, and Zapdos all immensely threaten Iron Moth; Ogerpon-W forces it out with STAB attacks and the threat of a Swords Dance, Archaludon forces it out with Earthquake, and Zapdos forces it out with Weather Ball or its STAB moves. All-out attacking Iron Moth sets struggle less against Primordial Sea users.

Roaring Moon: Roaring Moon, especially its bulkier sets, is particularly apt at switching into, checking, and OHKOing Iron Moth, forcing it out.

RegenVest Users: RegenVest users like Swampert and Meloetta effortlessly sponge Iron Moth's hits while threatening it hard in return.

Faster Attackers: Revenge killers like Chien-Pao, Deoxys-S, and Zamazenta can outspeed and cleanly OHKO Iron Moth.

Desolate Land.description:
Iron Moth functions as a great offensive pivot, leveraging its solid typing bolstered by Desolate Land, high Special Attack, solid bulk and Speed, and deep coverage movepool to soft-check powerful threats like Zapdos, Gholdengo, and Moltres. Fiery Dance is preferred to potentially turn Iron Moth into a dangerous setup sweeper, but bulky variants can opt for Flamethrower for more consistent damage overall as well as more PP. Solar Beam is the preferred second move, immediately threatening checks like Manaphy and Swampert. Toxic Spikes allows Iron Moth to wear down bulky RegenVest foes like Roaring Moon and Manaphy over time, while Sludge Wave threatens Zapdos, Scream Tail, and Primarina. U-turn allows Iron Moth to pivot out of disadvantageous matchups like Well-Baked Body Steel-types, incoming Primordial Sea users, and Swampert if lacking Solar Beam. An offensive spread is usually preferred, especially if running coverage moves, but alternatively, a set with maximum HP and Speed can be used to be a more effective switch-in to foes like Zapdos and Primarina.

Iron Moth finds itself best suited for balance or bulky offense teams that highly appreciate the combination of defensive utility and offensive firepower it brings. Offensive pivots like Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Slither Wing are especially great teammates, forming a potent VoltTurn core with Iron Moth. Roaring Moon threatens Psychic-types like Deoxys-S, Azelf, and Iron Crown while acting as a secondary check to Zapdos, which can otherwise come in on Iron Moth's Fire-type moves for free. Iron Moth, meanwhile, threatens the physical walls that Roaring Moon can struggle to make progress against. Iron Moth is incredibly vulnerable to Knock Off and, if its item gets removed, entry hazards, making Great Tusk and Corviknight amazing teammates. Even with specialized coverage, Iron Moth struggles to make progress against special walls like Swampert, Meloetta, and Chansey, and its Speed stat leaves much to be desired, meaning fast physical wallbreakers that can handle these special walls like Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Zamazenta are near mandatory; these teammates also greatly appreciate Toxic Spikes wearing down checks like Great Tusk and physically defensive Manaphy.

All-Out Attacker.description:
All-out Attacker Iron Moth serves as an excellent wallbreaker, utilizing its high base Special Attack and good coverage to break down common defensive options in the tier. When using Sheer Force, Fire Blast threatens to OHKO Zamazenta, Pecharunt, and Volcarona. Flamethrower can be opted for instead, trading in the ability to threaten the aforementioned KOs for accuracy. Fiery Dance should exclusively be used on Hadron Engine variants, as it allows Iron Moth to potentially spiral out of control in a single turn. Energy Ball is necessary for would-be checks like RegenVest Swampert and Manaphy. Discharge smacks Well-Baked Body Skarmory and Gholdengo and, hits Manaphy harder than Energy Ball if using Hadron Engine, and dissuades Roaring Moon from switching in with its nasty chance of paralysis, while Dazzling Gleam invalidates Roaring Moon as an answer to Iron Moth. Lastly, U-turn allows Iron Moth to pivot out in the face of checks it cannot beat, like Blissey, RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, and Meloetta. Life Orb pairs perfectly with Sheer Force, granting Iron Moth extra power with no drawback on its Sheer Force-boosted moves. Heavy-Duty Boots can be considered on Hadron Engine sets, allowing Iron Moth to disregard entry hazards.

Iron Moth truly shines on balance and more offensive teams looking for a wallbreaker that is near-impossible to switch into safely. Thus, other special wallbreakers and pivots like Azelf, Zapdos, and Hisuian Electrode appreciate Iron Moth's ability to overload their checks like RegenVest Manaphy, Swampert, and Roaring Moon. Defensive pivots like Corviknight, RegenVest Swampert, and Manaphy grant Iron Moth a backbone it can rely on to stomach hits in its place and pivot out; these Pokemon also can thwart revenge killing attempts from faster threats like Roaring Moon, Deoxys-S, and Chien-Pao. Iron Moth appreciates entry hazard removal from options like Great Tusk and Corviknight when not utilizing Heavy-Duty Boots. Iron Moth suffers from four-moveslot syndrome and as a result cannot threaten targets like RegenVest Roaring Moon without Dazzling Gleam and Well-Baked Body Skarmory and Gholdengo without Discharge; hence, teammates that can deal with these targets like Latios, Chien-Pao, and Choice Specs Primarina pair well with it.

Physically Defensive.description: Gholdengo's naturally good offensive presence, fantastic typing, and access to reliable recovery combine to make it a staple defensive piece. Hex can be run over Shadow Ball in conjunction with Thunder Wave to increase its maximum Base Power while spreading paralysis to support Gholdengo's teammates. Well-Baked Body allows Gholdengo to wall Pokemon reliant on Fire-type moves to beat it, such as Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Ogerpon-H lacking Knock Off. Similarly, Earth Eater handles opposing Ground-types such as non-Scrappy Great Tusk. Bulletproof is used to negate Shadow Ball from Gengar, Hisuian Zoroark, and opposing Gholdengo. Gholdengo's natural typing allows it to use nearly any immunity ability effectively, so options like Water Absorb and Volt Absorb can also be used depending on the needs of its team, although these are generally less effective. 28 Speed EVs are used to outspeed minimally invested Great Tusk, with the remaining EVs being used to maximize Gholdengo's physical bulk to better check physical attackers. Gholdengo is particularly vulnerable to Dark-types like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao, and many Pokemon like Iron Boulder and Ogerpon-C run Dark-type coverage specifically to hit all variants of it. Thus, Pokemon that can take hits from Dark-type attackers such as Corviknight and Great Tusk make good partners. Gholdengo cannot check most special attackers, so it appreciates having special walls such as Swampert and Manaphy as teammates. Finally, Gholdengo can be taken advantage of and used for momentum by RegenVest Pokemon such as Swampert and Meloetta, so it appreciates strong wallbreakers such as Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos to bust through these walls.

Choice Scarf.description: Thanks to its high base Special Attack that's further boosted by Adaptability, as well as its usable Speed that's improved by Choice Scarf, Gholdengo functions as a revenge killer and late-game cleaner. Trick allows Gholdengo to punish common switch-ins such as Swampert, Manaphy, and Empoleon, allowing teammates like Latios, Zapdos, and Primarina to deal more damage and beat their would-be checks. Recover, while it doesn't seem as though it would fit on a Choice Scarf Pokemon, is the preferred option in the fourth moveslot, as it greatly improves Gholdengo's longevity and becomes quite usable after it uses Trick. Focus Blast is a secondary option that provides a way for Gholdengo to hit bulky Steel-type Pokemon like Kingambit, Hisuian Goodra, and non-Bulletproof Empoleon; alternatively, Dazzling Gleam hits Roaring Moon, Latios, and Iron Hands. Adaptability, while boosting the power of Gholdengo's STAB moves and allows it to bluff immunity abilities such as Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater. Gholdengo threatens to outspeed and OHKO fast offensive threats such as Latios, Chien-Pao, and Iron Boulder but cannot switch safely into some of them. Gholdengo struggles against specially defensive walls such as Swampert, Empoleon, and Manaphy, so strong physical attackers like Ogerpon-H and Iron Hands can be used to beat them, and in return, while Ogerpon-H and Iron Hands appreciate Gholdengo's speed control. Gholdengo appreciates strong physical wallbreakers such as Roaring Moon and Zamazenta that improve its ability to clean, as well as slow pivots like Corviknight and Manaphy to help Gholdengo switch in safely.

Hadron Engine.description: Thanks to its high natural Special Attack further bostered by Hadron Engine as well as its decent Speed, Gholdengo functions as a menacing wallbreaker with Choice Specs, while it functions as speed control and as a revenge killer with Choice Scarf sets. Thunderbolt 2HKOes physically defensive RegenVest Manaphy, Primarina, and non-Volt Absorb Empoleon. Trick cripples common switch-ins to Gholdengo such as Swampert and Blissey, while Recover increases its longevity and allows it to switch in on certain attacks like Boomburst from Pixilate Scream Tail more consistently; alternatively, Dazzling Gleam nails Roaring Moon and Iron Hands. A Choice Scarf can be used to outspeed maximum Speed Great Tusk, Chien-Pao, and non-Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, but Choice Specs is an alternative option that allows Gholdengo to 2HKO specially defensive RegenVest Manaphy and Jirachi and pressure RegenVest users harder. Gholdengo pairs well with strong wallbreakers like Deoxys-S and Primarina, as they are able to break down bulky walls like Hisuian Goodra and Swampert, allowing Gholdengo to clean up. Gholdengo also pairs well with entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Garchomp, as the Spikes they set up can quickly wear down RegenVest Pokemon. While being a niche set, Surge Surfer Iron Hands pairs incredibly with Gholdengo, as it requires Electric Terrain to be up for it to function as a cleaner. Gholdengo struggles to find opportunities to safely switch in, so slow pivots such as Corviknight, Manaphy, and Swampert are appreciated. Hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight are necessary to prevent Gholdengo from being worn down by Spikes, especially if it's not running Recover. Gholdengo struggles against Heavy-Duty Boots Blissey and RegenVest Pokemon like Swampert and Hisuian Goodra, so Pokemon that can easily use Knock Off like Manaphy and Magic Guard Roaring Moon make for good partners.

Chien-Pao.comments:
Other Options

Adaptability can be used on non-Sacred Sword sets, obtaining a similar power boost while allowing Chien-Pao's teammates like Roaring Moon and Ceruledge to run the ability instead; it has the notable benefit of hiding Chien-Pao's ability from the opponent. Lash Out is an option on the Choice Band set to immediately dent Intimidate users like Corviknight and Skarmory on the switch but lacks power otherwise while missing out on valuable Defense drops. Psychic Fangs is another option for Choice Band variants to punish Zamazenta and Iron Hands on the switch, potentially 2HKO a would-be check in physically defensive Primarina after Stealth Rock, and remove dual screens set by foes like Regieleki and Corviknight, letting its team match up better against dual screens hyper offense teams. Ice Spinner may seem like an appealing option on Swords Dance sets for a little extra consistency, but the additional power, contact avoidance, and flinch chance of Icicle Crash makes it entirely preferable, leaving Ice Spinner unviable. Serene Grace sets are an option to fish for Icicle Crash flinches or Crunch Defense drops, but this set lacks power and is generally inferior to damage amplification abilities.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats: Foes like Zamazenta and Psychic Surge Deoxys-S can outspeed and OHKO Chien-Pao while not being particularly afraid of its priority moves.

Bulky Fighting-types: Bulky foes like Iron Hands, Cobalion, and Zamazenta can often easily switch in on Chien-Pao's Dark-type moves and use it to either pivot with Volt Switch or as setup fodder.

Primarina: Bulkier Primarina sets can switch in easily against Chien-Pao's STAB moves and either force it out with Moonblast or use it as Calm Mind fodder.

Entry Hazards: Entry hazard setters like Skarmory, Great Tusk, and Heatran can cause immense problems for non-Magic Guard sets due to their frailty being compounded by their hazard vulnerability.

Choice Band.description:
Thanks to its high Attack boosted further by Sword of Ruin, strong STAB combination, and access to priority moves, Choice Band Chien-Pao is one of the metagame's deadliest wallbreakers and revenge killers. On top of a valuable Speed tier to threaten and chase out common tier staples like Roaring Moon, Cinderace, and Iron Boulder, it has the immediate power to 2HKO walls like physically defensive Manaphy as well as Fluffy Corviknight and Skarmory after Stealth Rock. Sacred Sword immediately threatens Steel-type foes such as Kingambit, Cobalion, Heatran, and Iron Treads. Either priority move allows Chien-Pao to revenge kill faster threats like Hisuian Electrode and Choice Scarf Latios; Sucker Punch is more punishable but targets non-Psychic Surge Deoxys-S, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Agility Iron Crown hard, while Ice Shard handles foes like Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, and weakened Zamazenta.

Though it can function on a wide range of team styles, Chien-Pao fits best on fast-paced offensive teams that can best take advantage of its wallbreaking prowess while mitigating its lack of defensive utility. Powerful special wallbreakers like Deoxys-S, Gholdengo, and Primarine stand out as star teammates for their ability to immediately threaten physical walls like physically defensive Manaphy, Skarmory, and Iron Hands that can give Chien-Pao trouble. Also notable are Latios, Iron Moth, and Iron Crown, which are powerful special pivots able to bring Chien-Pao in to threaten their switch-ins like Swampert, Ting-Lu, and Roaring Moon. Chien-Pao also works well in tandem with other powerful wallbreakers like Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Iron Boulder, with Chien-Pao wearing down their checks like non-Intimidate Corviknight, Landorus, and Pecharunt, while its teammates pressure Manaphy, Iron Hands, and defensive Primarina. Bulky pivots like Pecharunt, Swampert, and Corviknight can also make good teammates, tanking hits and allowing the frail Chien-Pao to more easily get on the field against foes like Roaring Moon, Zapdos, and Scream Tail; Pecharunt is especially notable for its ability to wall Zamazenta, which is otherwise a great check to Chien-Pao, while Corviknight alongside Great Tusk and Iron Treads are noteworthy for their entry hazard removing capabilities, making it far easier for Chien-Pao to repeatedly hit the field.

Roaring Moon.comments:
Other Options

Dragon Dance sets can be run on dual screens hyper offense structures; Fluffy is a good option to aid in setup, and Weakness Policy takes advantage of slow pivots like Corviknight aiming to pivot with U-turn. Acrobatics is an additional option with Weakness Policy or a Terrain Seed to nail Great Tusk and Zamazenta. Lash Out is an option to punish Intimidate users like Corviknight and Skarmory, while Fire Blast and Fire Fang can heavily threaten Fluffy users, but usually, Knock Off and U-turn threaten them enough with entry hazard support. Offensive sets can run Roost to provide longevity and offset chip damage, Taunt to shut down Corviknight, or Iron Head to nail Scream Tail.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats: Zamazenta, Deoxys-S, and Meowscarada outspeed non-Choice Scarf Roaring Moon variants and force it out.

Bulky Dark-resistant Foes: Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Kingambit all can take Roaring Moon's STAB attacks and threaten it back with their STAB moves.

Entry Hazards: Non-Magic Guard Roaring Moon variants struggle heavily with chip damage, as they frequently switch and typically lack recovery.

Burns: Roaring Moon is crippled by burn and must be exceedingly cautions of switching into Fire-types that may carry Will-O-Wisp such as Heatran and Cinderace, as well as fearing Scald from Manaphy and Steam Eruption from Volcanion. It also fears the rare but punishing Flame Body.

Paralysis: Roaring Moon relies heavily on its Speed tier and can be punished by Thunder Wave from Gholdengo and Hisuian Electrode, which it would otherwise switch in freely on. Zapdos can also threaten it with paralysis from Thunder or Zap Cannon. Roaring Moon is also greatly punished by the rare Static.

Choice Item.description:
Roaring Moon's excellent Attack, Speed, and STAB coverage along with U-turn make it the premiere Choice item attacker. With Choice Scarf, Roaring Moon outspeeds every unboosted Pokemon, even Regieleki, and dangerous threats such Choice Scarf Latios and Gholdengo; only Choice Scarf Meowscarada outspeeds it. Choice Band Roaring Moon, on the other hand, is a ferocious wallbreaker that still outspeeds the crowded base 110 Speed tier, forcing out common Pokemon like the Ogerpon formes, Sandy Shocks, and Zapdos. Knock Off threatens to KO most offensive Pokemon while punishing switch-ins like Corviknight and Great Tusk with item removal. Outrage is an excellent late-game sweeping tool once Steel- and Fairy-types like Kingambit and Scream Tail have been weakened or removed. U-turn allows Roaring Moon to pivot out of bad matchups like Corviknight, safely revenge kill weakened offensive threats without prediction, and force switches from the opponent, hopefully through entry hazards after removing their Heavy-Duty Boots. Earthquake hits Iron Hands and Kingambit, while Stone Edge hits Moltres and Zapdos and lets Choice Band sets do non-negligible damage to Fluffy Corviknight. Sword of Ruin provides the most damage and impacts all of Roaring Moon's moves, while Tough Claws retains its power against opposing Sword of Ruin users, namely Zamazenta, and does not reveal itself on the switch in.

Roaring Moon fits best on balance and offensive teams that can take advantage of its power, Speed, and pivoting abilities and may also appreciate its defensive profile to help slow down certain key threats like Deoxys-S, Hisuian Electrode, and Gholdengo. Due to its frequent pivoting and lack of recovery, Roaring Moon abhors entry hazards, making Corviknight, Iron Treads, or Great Tusk nearly required as a teammate. Special walls like Manaphy can switch into special attacks aimed at Roaring Moon and appreciate its resistances to Electric, Ghost, and Psychic taking some of the pressure off of them as well. On the flip side, Roaring Moon forces frequent switches and removes Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off, making hazard-stacking teammates like Sandy Shocks, Great Tusk, and Skarmory excellent options. Fluffy walls, especially Corviknight, can give Roaring Moon a hard time, so strong Fire-type teammates like Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge are excellent options. Roaring Moon does not appreciate bulky Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Zamazenta, so it appreciates teammates that threaten them like Scream Tail and Deoxys-S. Roaring Moon pairs extremely well with other offensive pivots; it can team with special pivots like Iron Moth and Latios to bring each other in in favorable matchups or with physical pivots like Meowscarada and Cinderace to wear down their shared checks.

RegenVest.description:
Roaring Moon leverages a solid defensive typing with plenty of resistances alongside great Speed, Attack, bulk, and access to U-turn to be a great offensive RegenVest pivot, gluing together balance and bulky offense teams while bringing extra utility in the form of Knock Off. Earthquake is a solid coverage option that threatens Steel-type foes like Heatran, Iron Treads, and Hisuian Goodra as well as Iron Hands. Stone Edge is preferred as the final move for its ability to hit Zapdos and Moltres super effectively and Corviknight neutrally, but Dragon Tail gives Roaring Moon extra utility against setup sweepers like Gholdengo, Iron Crown, and Ursaluna-B, forcing them out. Throat Chop is an option as a secondary STAB move that notably disables Boomburst from Pixilate Scream Tail and Parting Shot from Pecharunt. 192 Speed EVs guarantee that Roaring Moon will outspeed Thundurus and non-Choice Scarf Scream Tail, with the rest put into Special Defense to increase Roaring Moon's bulk. Alternatively, a set with maximum Speed investment can be used to Speed tie with Cinderace and opposing Roaring Moon.

Roaring Moon fits best on pivot-heavy balance and offense teams that can take advantage of its typing and Speed to form potent VoltTurn cores while making its only decent bulk less of an issue. Roaring Moon struggles to check powerful Dragon- and Fairy-types like Latios, Primarina, and, if not running Throat Chop, Scream Tail, making a secondary specially defensive Pokemon like Iron Treads, Empoleon, or Heatran a great partner; in return, Roaring Moon naturally walls foes like Iron Moth, Gholdengo, and Sandy Shocks that can give these Steel-types issues. Roaring Moon is also easily forced out by powerful physical attackers like Chien-Pao, Great Tusk, and opposing offensive variants of Roaring Moon, making a physical wall like Pecharunt, Corviknight, or your own Great Tusk perfect partners. The last two are also notable for being the tier's best entry hazard removal options, helping to shore up Roaring Moon's relative weakness to entry hazards. Powerful offensive threats like Great Tusk, Latios, and Gholdengo all appreciate Roaring Moon's ability to aggressively scout the opponent's move and pivot them in safely, with the last two especially appreciating Roaring Moon's ability to remove Assault Vest from opposing Manaphy ​and Swampert.

Swords Dance.description: Fantastic STAB coverage, a solid Speed tier, and good coverage options all make Ogerpon-W a force to be reckoned with, being able to shatter most of the tier's physical walls such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Mandibuzz after a Swords Dance. Power Whip packs more of a punch, letting it OHKO RegenVest Manaphy without a Swords Dance boost, while Horn Leech grants it more longevity. Knock Off lets it threaten Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Heatran, while Play Rough picks off Dragon-types such as Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Latios. Trailblaze enables Ogerpon-W to act as more of a sweeper, letting it outspeed threats such as Iron Boulder, Chien-Pao, and Deoxys-S, while Spikes can be used to help chip down Hisuian Goodra and other walls for its teammates. Ogerpon-W pairs well with fast cleaners such as Iron Boulder and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, as they appreciate its ability to pressure Fluffy users such as Corviknight and Great Tusk thanks to Ivy Cudgel not making contact. In spite of its solid speed, Ogerpon-W is still threatened by faster targets such as Chien-Pao, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Roaring Moon, making defensive pivots such as Corviknight and Swampert crucial in order to bring it in safely.

All-Out Attacker.description: Ogerpon-W is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to its good stats and incredible movepool, featuring high Base Power STAB moves and strong coverage options. Power Whip is the standard Grass-type STAB move of choice due to its power, but Horn Leech can be used to avoid missing and provide Ogerpon-W with healing. Knock Off can hinder switch-ins like Intimidate Corviknight and Dragonite. Play Rough stops Dragonite from being a safe switch-in, as well as surprising Roaring Moon that try to switch in with an OHKO. U-turn allows Ogerpon-W to pivot out on bad matchups like the aforementioned Intimidate Corviknight and Dragonite. Stomping Tantrum hits Water-immune foes such as Water Absorb Heatran and Desolate Land Iron Moth and Ceruledge. Primordial Sea boosts Ogerpon-W's Ivy Cudgel to absurd levels, consistently 2HKOing non-Intimidate Corviknight while also giving Ogerpon-W a Fire immunity. Sword of Ruin is an alternative option to boost the power of all of Ogerpon-W's moves, notably OHKOing physically defensive Manaphy with Power Whip. Ogerpon-W pairs well with teammates like Zamazenta and Iron Boulder that can break through non-Fluffy Corviknight. It also appreciates Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk and Scream Tail, as they discourage Pokemon like Dragonite from switching in and help chip down defensive Pokemon. While Ogerpon-W's Speed tier is good, it can still get easily revenge killed by Pokemon like Roaring Moon, Deoxys-S, and Zamazenta, so a strong defensive core featuring teammates such as Manaphy and Corviknight is appreciated. Ogerpon-W struggles with switching in safely, so it appreciates slow pivots like the aforementioned Corviknight and Manaphy.

Physically Defensive.description: With Regenerator, a solid defensive typing, and high physical bulk, Archaludon acts as a good physical wall that can wear down the opposing team. Dragon Tail phazes setup sweepers like Iron Hands, Dragonite, and all Ogerpon formes, and Heavy Slam hits Fairy-types such as Scream Tail and Florges. Alternatively, Iron Defense benefits Body Press's damage output and renders Archaludon's matchup against physical setup sweepers better. As Archaludon forces switches with Dragon Tail, Stealth Rock further increases the chip damage it deals to the opposing team. Rocky Helmet lets Archaludon wear down pivots such as Barraskewda, Cinderace, and Roaring Moon. Archaludon covers a variety of physical attackers such as all Ogerpon formes, Roaring Moon, and Barraskewda, but it is overwhelmed by offensive wallbreakers like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Galarian Zapdos, so allies such as Fluffy Corviknight and Skarmory are much appreciated. Archaludon also appreciates Pokemon like Hisuian Electrode and the Ogerpon formes beating Swampert, which it can't make much progress against. Archaludon has poor Special Defense, which makes it vulnerable to special wallbreakers such as Heatran, Iron Moth, and Gengar, so it appreciates specially defensive allies like Blissey and Empoleon.

Offensive Entry Hazard Setter.description: Archaludon acts as a niche Stealth Rock setter that scares away common entry hazard removal options like Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Great Tusk with the combination of Electro Shot and Draco Meteor. Furthermore, Electro Shot + Primordial Sea allows Archaludon to threaten to snowball at a moment's notice. Earthquake smacks Desolate Land Iron Moth and Heatran attempting to come in on Electro Shot, while Body Press chunks checks like Blissey and Volt Absorb Empoleon. Primordial Sea allows Archaludon to offensively counter Iron Moth and grants it a one-turn Electro Shot. Additionally, Archaludon's good typing and natural physical bulk allow it to take on Zapdos and all Ogerpon formes in a pinch, but it should never be relied on to check them. Archaludon greatly struggles with its lack of Speed; as a result, fast offensive pivots that can bring it in safely like Roaring Moon, Azelf, and Walking Wake pair well with it, especially considering its ability to force hazard damage on their switch-ins, like Corviknight, Empoleon, and Manaphy. Archaludon's low Special Defense and Speed cause it to be susceptible to special attackers like Walking Wake, Azelf, and Pixilate Scream Tail, making pivots that can safely switch in to them like Empoleon, RegenVest Manaphy, and Swampert good partners.

Pecharunt.comments:
Other Options

Pecharunt can run almost any other immunity ability, such as Water Absorb or Well-Baked Body, to patch up a team-wide weakness, as it does not need the extra bulk from Fluffy or Intimidate to check threats that cannot hit it super effectively. Black Sludge is preferred for passive recovery but other items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Colbur Berry can be used to reduce damage from entry hazards and Knock Off from attackers like Roaring Moon, respectively. Nasty Plot is an option to provide a bulky wincon on slower teams, but Pecharunt is extremely easy to force out by most special attackers. Foul Play is an option to punish physical setup attackers and absolutely nuke Iron Boulder, but Toxic, Parting Shot, and Destiny Bond already deter most setup users and have more utility.

Checks and Counters

Dark-type Physical Attackers: Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Meowscarada can all hit Pecharunt with powerful attacks, and Prankster variants are also unable to pivot against them.

Special Attackers: Most special attackers can take advantage of Pecharunt's lower Special Defense and force it out.

Bulky Steel-types: Bulky Steel-types like Heatran and especially Kingambit do not fear any common move from Pecharunt and can safely come in to set hazards or attack.

Prankster.description:
Prankster Pecharunt leverages its excellent bulk, typing, and utility movepool to serve as an aggressive pivot on balance and offensive teams. Pecharunt is able to come in against a myriad of physical threats like Iron Hands, Zamazenta, and the Ogerpon formes to absorb their attacks and then pivot in a teammate safely with Parting Shot. It can even come in aggressively against foes like Great Tusk and Iron Boulder that pack super effective STAB moves; even if they used the correct move and deal significant damage, it can safely pivot out thanks to Prankster and Recover next time it comes in. Destiny Bond provides insurance against setup sweepers, especially Speed-boosting ones like Roaring Moon, and allows Pecharunt to trade itself at low health or in a poor matchup. Malignant Chain is the best attack due to its power and poison chance, which deters Dark-types like Meowscarada and non-Magic Guard Roaring Moon from switching in, but Shadow Ball and Night Shade are options to hit Steel-types and have significantly more PP for longer games. Since it should be pivoting frequently, Heavy-Duty Boots is the best item to dodge entry hazard chip damage. 0 Speed IVs allow Pecharunt to alternate between fast Destiny Bonds and slow attacks to almost always keep the effect active.

Prankster Pecharunt works best on balance and offensive teams that want to safely switch in their offensive threats but still have some semblance of a defensive backbone. Frail but powerful teammates like Deoxys-S, Chien-Pao, and Iron Boulder love the relatively free switch ins Pecharunt provides after Parting Shot. Pecharunt pairs very well with RegenVest users like Manaphy and Swampert, as they both provide pivoting and blanket check special attackers; Parting Shot also gives them more opportunities to switch into weak attacks to heal with Regenerator. Pecharunt's bulk, Parting Shot, and Destiny Bond all force frequent switches, making entry hazard setters like Great Tusk and Skarmory good teammates. Pecharunt struggles with Dark-types like Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, and Chien-Pao, as they block Parting Shot and can hit it hard, so a strong physically defensive switch-in like Intimidate Corviknight is recommended; powerful Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Great Tusk can also deter them. It is also worth noting that Prankster Pecharunt has extremely poor synergy with Psychic Surge users like Azelf and Deoxys-S, as they will block Parting Shot, so it should not be run with them.
